title
:
<EOS>
Old
Saint
Paul
's
       
A
Tale
of
the
Plague
and
the
Fire
author
:
<EOS>
William
Harrison
Ainsworth
    
<EOS>
the
portion
of
the
ensue
Tale
relate
to
the
Grocer
of
Wood
-
street
,
and
his
manner
of
victual
his
house
,
and
shut
up
himself
and
his
family
within
it
during
the
bad
part
of
the
Plague
of
1665
,
be
found
on
a
narrative
,
which
I
have
follow
pretty
closely
in
most
of
its
detail
,
contain
in
a
very
rare
little
volume
,
entitle
,
"
_
preparation
against
the
Plague
,
both
of
Soul
and
Body
_
,
"
the
authorship
of
which
I
have
no
hesitation
in
assigning
to
DEFOE
.
<EOS>
indeed
,
I
venture
to
pronounce
it
his
masterpiece
.
<EOS>
It
be
strange
that
this
matchless
performance
should
have
hitherto
escape
attention
,
and
that
it
should
not
have
be
reprint
with
some
one
of
the
countless
impression
of
the
"
_
history
of
the
Plague
of
London
_
,
"
to
which
it
form
an
almost
necessary
accompaniment
.
<EOS>
the
omission
,
I
trust
,
will
be
repair
by
Mr.
HAZLITT
the
young
,
DEFOE
's
last
and
good
editor
,
in
his
valuable
edition
of
the
work
of
that
great
novelist
and
political
writer
,
now
in
the
course
of
publication
.
<EOS>
It
may
be
add
,
that
a
case
precisely
similar
to
that
of
the
Grocer
,
and
attend
with
the
same
happy
result
,
occur
during
the
Plague
of
Marseilles
,
in
1720
.
 
<EOS>
for
my
acquaintance
with
this
narrative
,
as
well
as
for
the
suggestion
of
its
application
to
the
present
purpose
,
I
be
indebted
to
my
friend
,
Mr.
JAMES
CROSSLEY
,
of
Manchester
.

<EOS>
OLD
SAINT
paul's.
   
book
<EOS>
the
first
.
 
<EOS>
APRIL
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
the
grocer
of
wood
-
STREET
and
his
FAMILY
.
 
<EOS>
one
night
,
at
the
latter
end
of
April
,
1665
,
the
family
of
a
citizen
of
London
carry
on
an
extensive
business
as
a
grocer
in
wood
-
street
,
Cheapside
,
be
assemble
,
accord
to
custom
,
at
prayer
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
's
name
be
Stephen
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
His
family
consist
of
his
wife
,
three
son
,
and
two
daughter
.
<EOS>
He
have
,
moreover
,
an
apprentice
;
an
elderly
female
serving
as
cook
;
her
son
,
a
young
man
about
five
-
and
-
twenty
,
fill
the
place
of
porter
to
the
shop
and
general
assistant
;
and
a
kitchen
-
maid
.
<EOS>
the
whole
household
attend
;
for
the
worthy
grocer
,
be
a
strict
observer
of
his
religious
duty
,
as
well
as
a
rigid
disciplinarian
in
other
respect
,
suffer
no
one
to
be
absent
,
on
any
plea
<EOS>
whatever
,
except
indisposition
,
from
morning
and
evening
devotion
;
and
these
be
always
perform
at
stated
time
.
<EOS>
in
fact
,
the
establishment
be
conduct
with
the
regularity
of
clockwork
,
it
be
the
aim
of
its
master
not
to
pass
a
single
hour
of
the
day
unprofitably
.
 
<EOS>
the
ordinary
prayer
go
through
,
Stephen
Bloundel
offer
up
along
and
fervent
supplication
to
the
most
high
for
protection
against
the
devour
pestilence
with
which
the
city
be
then
scourge
.
<EOS>
He
acknowledge
that
this
terrible
visitation
have
be
justly
bring
upon
it
by
the
wickedness
of
its
inhabitant
;
that
they
deserve
their
doom
,
dreadful
though
it
be
;
that
,
like
the
dweller
in
Jerusalem
before
it
be
give
up
to
ruin
and
desolation
,
they
"
have
mock
the
messenger
of
God
and
despise
His
word
;
"
that
in
the
language
of
the
prophet
,
"
they
have
refuse
to
hearken
,
and
pull
away
the
shoulder
,
and
stop
their
ear
that
they
should
not
hear
;
yea
,
have
make
their
heart
like
an
adamant
stone
,
lest
they
should
hear
the
law
and
the
word
which
the
Lord
of
Hosts
have
send
in
his
spirit
by
the
former
prophet
.
"
<EOS>
He
admit
that
great
sin
require
great
chastisement
,
and
that
the
sin
of
London
be
enormous
;
that
it
be
fill
with
strife
,
sedition
,
heresy
,
murder
,
drunkenness
,
revelling
,
and
every
kind
of
abomination
;
that
the
ordinance
of
God
be
neglect
,
and
all
manner
of
vice
openly
practise
;
that
,
despite
repeat
warning
and
affliction
less
grievous
than
the
present
,
these
vicious
practice
have
be
persist
in
.
<EOS>
all
this
he
humbly
acknowledge
.
<EOS>
but
he
implore
a
gracious
Providence
,
in
consideration
of
his
few
faithful
servant
,
to
spare
the
other
yet
a
little
longer
,
and
give
them
a
last
chance
of
repentance
and
amendment
;
or
,
if
this
could
not
be
,
and
their
utter
extirpation
be
inevitable
,
that
the
habitation
of
the
devout
may
be
exempt
from
the
general
destruction
--
may
be
place
of
refuge
,
as
Zoar
be
to
Lot
.
<EOS>
He
conclude
by
earnestly
exhort
those
around
him
to
keep
constant
watch
upon
themselves
;
not
to
murmur
at
God
's
dealing
and
dispensation
;
but
so
to
comport
themselves
,
that
"
they
may
be
able
to
stand
in
the
day
of
wrath
,
in
the
day
of
death
,
and
in
the
day
of
judgment
.
"
<EOS>
the
exhortation
produce
a
powerful
effect
upon
its
hearer
,
and
they
arise
,
some
with
serious
,
other
with
terrified
look
.
 
<EOS>
before
proceed
further
,
it
may
be
desirable
to
show
in
what
manner
the
dreadful
pestilence
refer
to
by
the
grocer
commence
,
and
how
far
its
ravage
have
already
extend
.
<EOS>
two
year
before
,
namely
,
in
1663
,
more
than
a
third
of
the
population
of
Amsterdam
be
carry
off
by
a
desolating
plague
.
<EOS>
Hamburgh
be
also
grievously
afflict
about
the
same
time
,
and
in
the
same
manner
.
<EOS>
notwithstanding
every
effort
to
cut
off
communication
with
these
state
,
the
insidious
disease
find
its
way
into
England
by
mean
of
some
bale
of
merchandise
,
as
it
be
suspect
,
at
the
latter
end
of
the
year
1664
,
when
two
person
die
suddenly
,
with
undoubted
symptom
of
the
distemper
,
in
Westminster
.
<EOS>
Its
next
appearance
be
at
a
house
in
Long
Acre
,
and
its
victim
two
frenchman
,
who
have
bring
good
from
the
levant
.
<EOS>
smother
for
a
short
time
,
like
a
fire
upon
which
coal
have
be
heap
,
it
break
out
with
fresh
fury
in
several
place
.
 
<EOS>
the
consternation
now
begin
.
<EOS>
the
whole
city
be
panic
-
stricken
:
nothing
be
talk
of
but
the
plague
--
nothing
plan
but
mean
of
arrest
its
progress
--
<EOS>
one
grim
and
ghastly
idea
possess
the
mind
of
all
.
<EOS>
like
a
hideous
phantom
stalk
the
street
at
noon
-
day
,
and
scare
all
in
its
path
,
Death
take
his
course
through
London
,
and
select
his
prey
at
pleasure
.
<EOS>
the
alarm
be
further
increase
by
the
prediction
confidently
make
as
to
the
vast
number
who
would
be
sweep
away
by
the
visitation
;
by
the
prognostication
of
astrologer
;
by
the
prophesying
of
enthusiast
;
by
the
denunciation
of
preacher
,
and
by
the
portent
and
prodigy
report
to
have
occur
.
<EOS>
during
the
long
and
frosty
winter
precede
this
fatal
year
,
a
comet
appear
in
the
heavens
,
the
sickly
colour
of
which
be
suppose
to
forebode
the
judgment
about
to
follow
.
<EOS>
blaze
star
and
other
meteor
,
of
a
lurid
hue
and
strange
and
preternatural
shape
,
be
likewise
see
.
<EOS>
the
sun
be
say
to
have
set
in
stream
of
blood
,
and
the
moon
to
have
show
without
reflect
a
shadow
;
grisly
shape
appear
at
night
--
<EOS>
strange
clamour
and
groan
be
hear
in
the
air
--
<EOS>
hearse
,
coffin
,
and
heap
of
unburied
dead
be
discover
in
the
sky
,
and
great
cake
and
clot
of
blood
be
find
in
the
Tower
moat
;
while
a
marvellous
double
tide
occur
at
London
Bridge
.
<EOS>
all
these
prodigy
be
currently
report
,
and
in
most
case
believe
.
 
<EOS>
the
severe
frost
,
before
notice
,
do
not
break
up
till
the
end
of
February
,
and
with
the
thaw
the
plague
frightfully
increase
in
violence
.
<EOS>
from
Drury
-
lane
it
spread
along
Holborn
,
eastward
as
far
as
Great
Turnstile
,
and
westward
to
Saint
Giles
's
Pound
,
and
so
along
the
Tyburn
-
road
.
<EOS>
Saint
Andrew
's
,
Holborn
,
be
next
infect
;
and
as
this
be
a
much
more
populous
parish
than
the
former
,
the
death
be
more
numerous
within
it
.
<EOS>
for
a
while
,
the
disease
be
check
by
Fleet
Ditch
;
it
then
leap
this
narrow
boundary
,
and
ascend
the
opposite
hill
,
carry
fearful
devastation
into
Saint
James
's
,
Clerkenwell
.
<EOS>
at
the
same
time
,
it
attack
Saint
Bride
's
;
thin
the
rank
of
the
thievish
horde
haunt
Whitefriars
,
and
proceed
in
a
westerly
course
,
decimate
Saint
Clement
Danes
.
 
<EOS>
Hitherto
,
the
city
have
escape
.
<EOS>
the
destroyer
have
not
pass
Ludgate
or
Newgate
,
but
environ
the
wall
like
a
besiege
enemy
.
<EOS>
a
few
day
,
however
,
before
the
opening
of
this
history
,
fine
weather
have
commence
,
the
horrible
disease
begin
to
grow
more
rife
,
and
laugh
all
precaution
and
impediment
to
scorn
,
break
out
in
the
very
heart
of
the
stronghold
--
namely
,
in
Bearbinder
-
lane
,
near
Stock
's
Market
,
where
nine
person
die
.
 
<EOS>
at
a
season
so
awful
,
it
may
be
imagine
how
an
impressive
address
,
like
that
deliver
by
the
grocer
,
would
be
receive
by
those
who
see
in
the
pestilence
,
not
merely
an
overwhelming
scourge
from
which
few
could
escape
,
but
a
direct
manifestation
of
the
Divine
displeasure
.
<EOS>
not
a
word
be
say
.
<EOS>
Blaize
Shotterel
,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Leonard

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
have

-

,

.
<EOS>
not

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
bring

,

.
<EOS>
by

,

.
<EOS>

,

"

"

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Amabel
's

.
<EOS>

omit
that

,

,

,

's

<EOS>
no

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

pity

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

_

"

"

<EOS>

,

cook
,
who
have
live
with
her
master
ever
since
his
marriage
,
and
have
the
strong
attachment
for
him
,
be
a
hale
,
stout
dame
,
of
about
sixty
,
with
few
infirmity
for
her
year
,
and
with
less
asperity
of
temper
than
generally
belong
to
servant
of
her
class
.
<EOS>
She
be
a
native
of
Holland
,
and
come
to
England
early
in
life
,
where
she
marry
Blaize
's
father
,
who
die
soon
after
their
union
.
<EOS>
an
excellent
cook
in
a
plain
way
--
indeed
,
she
have
no
practice
in
any
other
--
she
would
brew
strong

and

,
or
mix
a
sack
-
posset
with
,
any
innkeeper
in
the
city
.
<EOS>
moreover
,
she
be
a

and

,
if
her

be
ever
require
in
that

.
<EOS>
the
child
look
upon
her
as
a
second
mother
;
and
her
affection
for
them
,
which
be
unbounded
,
deserve
their
regard
.
<EOS>
She
be
a
perfect
storehouse
of
what
be
term
"
old
woman
's
receipt
;
"
and
there
be
few
complaint
(
except
the
plague
)
for
which
she
do
not
think
herself
qualified
to
prescribe
and
able

.
<EOS>
Her
skill
in
the

art
be
often
test
by
her

,
who
require

to

,
as

,
for
such
of
the
poor
of
the
parish
as

for

at

.
 
<EOS>
Her
son
,
Blaize
,
be
a
stout
,
stumpy
fellow
,
about
four

ten
,
with
a
head
somewhat
too
large
for
his
body
,
and
extremely
long

.
<EOS>
ever
since
the
plague
have
break

in

-

,
it
haunt

like
a
spectre
,
and
scatter
the
few
faculty
he
possess
.
<EOS>
in

he
try
to
combat
his
alarm
--
in
vain
his
mother
endeavour
to
laugh

.
<EOS>
nothing
would
do
.
<EOS>
He
read
the
bill
of
mortality
daily
;
ascertain

particular
of
every
case
;
dilate
upon
the
agony
of
the
sufferer
;
watch
the
progress
of

infection
,
and
calculate

would
take
to
reach
wood
-

.
<EOS>
He
talk
of
the

by

,
and
dream
of

night
;
and
more
than

house

,

that
he
be

.
<EOS>
by

's

,

steep

,

,
and

,

that
he
could

,

in

,
compound
of

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
He
likewise

,
or

,
if

suppose

.
<EOS>
a

be

,
as

.
<EOS>
every
nostrum
sell
by

quack
in

tempt

;
and

,

have

in

.
<EOS>
be

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
His

have

,

he
would

in

on
the
20th

,

.
<EOS>

be

,

have

attachment
for
Patience
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
but

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
a

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
guide

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

be

.

.

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

if

disobey
the
Lord
Mayor
's
order
,
and

give
information
,
we
shall
all
be
send
to

,
while

will
be
take

.
<EOS>
besides
,
the

will
be
here

.
<EOS>
They
be
sure
to
learn
what
have
happen
from
Doctor

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
true
,
true
,
"

;
"
I
have
forget

.
<EOS>
let

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
what
!
<EOS>
would

your

,

,

?
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
out

!
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

but

;

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
no

,

"

.
"
<EOS>
but

,

.
<EOS>
as

.
<EOS>
one

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

.

"

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
It

,

,

<EOS>

,

be

--

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>

_

_

"

<EOS>

,

collect

,

.
<EOS>
this

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

above

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
originally

,
upon

,

.
<EOS>
He
be

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

!

.

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
knock

,

,

,

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

<EOS>

's
,

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

-

-
le

,

.
<EOS>
He
then

through

.
<EOS>
He
be

.
<EOS>
Most

have

--

,

,

,

,
"

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
involuntarily

,

.
<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

--

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

and

coffin
be
bring
out
and
place
in
the
cart
.
<EOS>
this
do
,
the
driver
,
who
be
smoke

pipe
,

,
and
put

in

.
 
<EOS>
shrink
into
a

,
and
hold
a

to

,
to
avoid
breathe
the

,
Leonard
see
that

be

in

,
and

be
follow

two

.
<EOS>
the

itself
,

,

,

,

,

,

of

,

.
<EOS>
to

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

be

,
"
be

,

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
what
,
be

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

_

;

,

.
<EOS>

friend

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

's
.
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

twelve
!
"

IV

<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

,

infect

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
the
LIBERTINE
PUNISHED
.
 
<EOS>
Sir
Paul
Parravicin
and
Major
Pillichody
arrive
without
any
particular
adventure
at
the
top
of
the
Haymarket
,
where
the
former
dismiss
the
coach
he
have
hire
in
Cheapside
,
and
they
proceed
towards
piccadilly
on
foot
.
<EOS>
up
to
this
time
the
major
have
be
in
very
high
spirit
,
boast
what
he
would
do
,
in
case
they
encounter
Disbrowe
,
and
offer
to
keep
guard
outside
the
door
while
the
knight
remain
in
the
house
.
<EOS>
but
he
now
begin
to
alter
his
tone
,

from
both
.
 
<EOS>
"
Disbrowe
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Margaret
,
at
length
,
raise

in
bed
,
"
you
have
deeply
--
irrecoverably
injure

.
<EOS>
but

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

<EOS>
"

.
"
 
<EOS>

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
nothing

he

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
if

,
by

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Margaret
!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

have

!
"
 
<EOS>
"
what
do
that

?
<EOS>
I

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
you

.
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

of
plague

,

's

.
<EOS>

close

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

,

among

.
<EOS>

,

,

-

.
 
<EOS>
on
see
Mrs.

,

could

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

,

)

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

,

,

,

;

wear

.

.

.

,

blood

,

.
<EOS>
leave

,

,

's

.

?

,

,

;

.

!

,

.

.

,

.

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
Woe
!
<EOS>
woe
!
"
    
<EOS>
BOOK
the
second
.
 
<EOS>
MAY
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
progress
of
the
PESTILENCE
.
 
<EOS>
towards
the
middle
of
May
,
the
bill
of
mortality
begin
to
swell
greatly
in
amount
,
and
though
but
few
be
put
down
to
the
plague
,
and
a
large
number
to
the
spot
fever
(
another
frightful
disorder
rage
at
the
period
)
,
it
be
well
known
that
the
bulk
have
die
of
the
former
disease
.
<EOS>
the
rigorous
measure
adopt
by
the
authority
(
whether
salutary
or
not
have
be
question
)
,
in
shut
up
house
and
confine
the
sick
and
sound
within
them
for
forty
day
,
be
find
so
intolerable
,
that
most
person
be
dispose
to
run
any
risk
rather
than
be
subject
to
such
a
grievance
,
and
every
artifice
be
resort
to
for
conceal
a
case
when
it
occur
.
<EOS>
hence
,
it
seldom
happen
,
unless
by
accident
,
that
a
discovery
be
make
.
<EOS>
Quack
doctor
be
secretly
consult
,
instead
of
the
regular
practitioner
;
the
searcher
be
bribe
to
silence
;
and
large
fee
be
give
to
the
undertaker
and
burier
to
lay
the
death
to
the
account
of
some
other
disorder
.
<EOS>
all
this
,
however
,
do
not
blind
the
eye
of
the
officer
to
the
real
state
of
thing
.
<EOS>
redouble
their
vigilance
,
they
enter
house
on
mere
suspicion
;
inflict
punishment
where
they
find
their
order
disobey
or
neglect
;
send
the
sound
to
prison,--the
sick
to
the
pest
-
house
;
and
replace
the
faithless
searcher
by
other
upon
whom
they
could
place
reliance
.
<EOS>
many
case
be
thus
detect
;
but
in
spite
of
every
precaution
,
the
majority
escape
;
and
the
vent
be
no
sooner
stop
in
one
quarter
than
it
break
out
with
additional
violence
in
another
.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
the
alarm
have
become
general
.
<EOS>
all
whose
business
or
pursuit
permit
it
,
prepared
to
leave
London
,
which
they
regard
as
a
devoted
city
,
without
delay
.
<EOS>
as
many
house
be
,
therefore
,
close
from
the
absence
of
the
inhabitant
as
from
the
presence
of
the
plague
,
and
this
add
to
the
forlorn
appearance
of
the
street
,
which
in
some
quarter
be
almost
desert
.
<EOS>
for
a
while
,
nothing
be
see
at
the
great
outlet
of
the
city
but
cart
,
carriage
,
and
other
vehicle
,
fill
with
good
and
movable
,
on
their
way
to
the
country
;
and
,
as
may
be
suppose
,
the
departure
of
their
friend
do
not
tend
to
abate
the
dejection
of
those
whose
affair
compel
them
to
remain
behind
.
 
<EOS>
one
circumstance
must
not
be
pass
unnoticed
,
namely
,
the
continue
fineness
and
beauty
of
the
weather
.
<EOS>
no
rain
have
fall
for
upward
of
three
week
.
<EOS>
the
sky
be
bright
and
cloudless
;
the
atmosphere
,
apparently
,
pure
and
innoxious
;
while
the
heat
be
as
great
as
be
generally
experience
in
the
middle
of
summer
.
<EOS>
but
instead
of
produce
its
usual
enlivening
effect
on
the
spirit
,
the
fine
weather
add
to
the
general
gloom
and
apprehension
,
inasmuch
as
it
lead
to
the
belief
(
afterwards
fully
confirm
)
,
that
if
the
present
warmth
be
so
pernicious
,
the
more
sultry
season
which
be
near
at
hand
would
aggravate
the
fury
of
the
pestilence
.
<EOS>
sometimes
,
indeed
,
when
the
death
be
less
numerous
,
a
hope
begin
to
be
entertain
that
the
distemper
be
abate
,
and
confidence
be
for
a
moment
restore
;
but
these
anticipation
be
speedily
check
by
the
reappearance
of
the
scourge
,
which
seem
to
baffle
and
deride
all
human
skill
and
foresight
.
 
<EOS>
London
now
present
a
lamentable
spectacle
.
<EOS>
not
a
street
but
have
a
house
in
it
mark
with
a
red
cross
--
some
street
have
many
such
.
<EOS>
the
bell
be
continually
toll
for
burial
,
and
the
dead
-
cart
go
their
melancholy
round
at
night
and
be
constantly
load
.
<EOS>
fresh
direction
be
issue
by
the
authority
;
and
as
domestic
animal
be
consider
to
be
a
medium
of
convey
the
infection
,
an
order
,
which
be
immediately
carry
into
effect
,
be
give
to

all
dog
and

.
<EOS>
but
this

prove
prejudicial
rather
than
the

,
as
the
body
of
the
poor
animal
,
most

which
be

in
the

,
be
wash

,
produce
a
horrible
and
noxious

,
suppose
to
contribute

to
the
propagation
of
the
distemper
.
 
<EOS>
no

measure
be
neglect
;
but
it
may
be
doubt

human

could
have
avert

of

scourge
,
which
,

may
be
check
for

day
by

,

,
would
in
the

have

.
<EOS>
the
College
of

,
by
the

's
command
,
issue
simple
and
intelligible
direction
,
in
the
mother

,
for
the
sick
.
<EOS>
certain

,

reader

,
Doctor

,
be

;

be
require

duly

office
.
<EOS>
public

and

be
likewise

.
<EOS>
but

seem
deaf
to

the
doom

--
their

be
follow

.
<EOS>
a

be

within
Saint
Paul
's
to

,

;

,
and
,
on
be

,

.
 
<EOS>
on

,

,
many

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

have

mention

,

<EOS>

,

the

,

<EOS>
about

.
<EOS>
the

,

<EOS>
the

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
greedily

.
<EOS>
head

"

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
he
add
,
"
be
it
your
opinion
that
our
poor
delude
child
still
entertain
any
regard
for
this
profligate
nobleman
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
sure
she
do
,
"
reply
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
and
it
be
from
that
conviction
that
I
so
strongly
urge
the
necessity
of
marry
her
to
Leonard
Holt
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
compel
her
to
do
anything
to
endanger
her
future
happiness
,
"
return
the
grocer
.
<EOS>
"
She
must
not
marry
Leonard
Holt
without
love
him
.
<EOS>
It
be
well
to
risk
an
uncertain
evil
,
than
to
rush
upon
a
certain
one
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
then
I
will
not
answer
for
the
consequence
,
"
reply
his
wife
.
 
<EOS>
"
what
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Bloundel
;
"
be
I
to
understand
you
have
no
reliance
on
Amabel
?
<EOS>
have
all
our
care
be
throw
away
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
distrust
her
,
"
return
Mrs.
Bloundel
;
"
but
consider
whom
she
have
to
deal
with
.
<EOS>
She
be
beset
by
the
handsome
and
most
fascinating
man
of
the
day
--
by
one
understand
to
be
practise
in
all
the
art
most
dangerous
to
our
sex
--
and
a
nobleman
to
boot
.
<EOS>
some
allowance
must
be
make
for
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
none
,
"
rejoin
Bloundel
,
austerely
.
"
<EOS>
She
have
be
teach
to
resist
temptation
in
whatever
guise
it
may
present
itself
;
and
if
the
principle
I
have
endeavour
to
implant
within
her
breast
have
find
lodgment
there
,
she
_
would
_
have
resist
it
.
<EOS>
I
be
deeply
grieve
to
find
this
be
not
the
case
,
and
that
she
must
trust
to
other
for
protection
,
when
she
ought
to
be
able
to
defend
herself
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
the
subject
be
not
further
discuss
,
and
the
grocer
and
his
wife
shortly
afterwards
retire
to
rest
.
 
<EOS>
on
the
following
morning
,
Bloundel
remark
to
the
apprentice
as
they
stand
together
in
the
shop
,
"
Leonard
,
you
be
aware
I
be
about
to
shut
up
my
house
.
<EOS>
before
do
so
,
I
must
make
certain
needful
arrangement
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
disguise
from
you
that
I
should
prefer
your
remain
with
me
,
but
at
the
same
time
I
beg
you
distinctly
to
understand
that
I
will
not
detain
you
against
your
will
.
<EOS>
Your
article
be
within
two
month
of
expire
;
and
,
if
you
desire
it
,
I
will
deliver
them
to
you
to
-
morrow
,
and
release
you
from
the
rest
of
your
time
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
not
desire
it
,
sir
,
"
reply
Leonard
;
"
I
will
remain
as
long
as
I
can
be
serviceable
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
take
time
for
reflection
,
"
rejoin
his
master
,
kindly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
in
all
probability
,
it
will
be
a
long
confinement
,
and
you
may
repent
,
when
too
late
,
have
subject
yourself
to
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
last
month
's
experience
have
teach
me
what
I
have
to
expect
,
"
remark
Leonard
,
with
a
smile
.
<EOS>
"
My
mind
be
make
up
,
I
will
stay
with
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
glad
of
it
,
"
return
Bloundel
,
"
and
now
I
have
something
further
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
My
wife
have
acquaint
me
with
the
daring
attempt
of
the
Earl
of
Rochester
to
carry
off
Amabel
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
have
my
mistress
,
also
,
tell
you
of
my
attachment
to
your
daughter
?
"
demand
Leonard
,
tremble
,
in
spite
of
his
effort
to
maintain
a
show
of
calmness
.
 
<EOS>
Bloundel
nod
an
affirmative
.
 
<EOS>
"
and
of
Amabel
's
promise
to
bestow
her
hand
upon
me
,
if
I
claim
it
at
the
month
's
end
?
"
continue

apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
"
no
!
"
reply
the
grocer
,
a
good
deal
<EOS>
surprised--"I
hear
of
no
such
promise
.
<EOS>
nor
be
I
aware
the
matter
have
go
so
far
.
<EOS>
but
have
you
claim
it
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
,
"
reply
Leonard
;
"
but
she
decline
give
an
answer
till
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
We
will
have
it
,
then
,
at
once
,
"
cry
Bloundel
"
come
with
me
to
her
.
"
 
<EOS>
so
say
,
he
lead
the
way
to
the
inner
room
,
where
they
find
Amabel
and
her
mother
.
<EOS>
at
the
sight
of
Leonard
,
the
former
instantly
cast
down
her
eye
.
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
say
her
father
,
in
a
tone
of
great
severity
than
he
have
ever
before
use
towards
her
,
"
all
that
have
pass
be
know
to
me
.
<EOS>
I
shall
take
another
and
more
fitting
opportunity
to
speak
to
you
on
your
ill
-
advise
conduct
.
<EOS>
I
be
come
for
a
different
purpose
.
<EOS>
You
have
give
Leonard
Holt
a
promise
(
I
need
not
tell
you
of
what
nature
)
,
and
he
claim
its

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
if
he
insist
upon
my
compliance
,
"
reply
Amabel
,
in
a

voice
,
"
I
must
obey
.
<EOS>
but
it
will
make
me
wretched
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
then
I
at
once
release
you
,
"
reply
Leonard
.
<EOS>
"
I
value
your
happiness
far
more
than
my
own
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
deserve
well
treatment
,
Leonard
,
"
say
Bloundel
;
"
and
I
be
sorry
my
daughter
can
not
discern
what
be
for
her
good
.
<EOS>
let
us
hope
that
time
will
work
a
change
in
your
favour
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
"
reply
the
apprentice
,
bitterly
;
"
I
will
no
longer
delude
myself
with
any
such
vain
expectation
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Amabel
,
"
observe
the

,
"
as
your
father
--
as
your
wellwisher
--
I
should
desire
to
see

wed
to
Leonard
.
<EOS>
but
I
have
tell
your
mother
,
and
now
tell

,
that
I
will
not
control
your
inclination
,
and
will
only
attempt
to
direct
you
so
far
as
I
think
likely
to
be
conducive
to
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
on
another
point
,
I
must
assume
a
very
different
tone
.
<EOS>
You
can
no
longer
plead
ignorance
of
the
design
of
the
depraved
person
who
beset

.
<EOS>
You
may
not
be
able
to
forget
him
--
but
you
can
avoid
him
.
<EOS>
if
you
see
him
alone
again
--
if
but

--
I
cast
you
off
for
ever
.
<EOS>
yes
,
for

,
"
he
repeat
,
with
stern

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
never
voluntarily
see
him
again
,
"
reply
Amabel
,
tremblingly
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
have
hear
my
determination
,
"
rejoin

father
.
<EOS>
"
do
you
still
adhere
to
your
resolution
of
remain
with
me
,
Leonard
?
"
<EOS>
he
add
,

.
<EOS>
"
if
what
have
just
pass
make
any

in
your
wish
,
state
so
,
frankly
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
stay
,
"
reply
Leonard
.
 
<EOS>
"
there
will
be
one
advantage
,
which
I
do
not

,
in
close

,
"
remark

grocer
aside

.
<EOS>
"
It
will
effectually
keep
away
this
libertine

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
perhaps

,
"
reply

other
.
"
<EOS>
but
I
have
more
faith
in
my
own

than
in
bolt
and
bar
.
<EOS>
"
 
Bloundel
and
Leonard
then
return
to
the
shop
,
where
the
former
immediately
begin
to
make
preparation
for
store
his
house
;
and
in
the
prosecution
of
his
scheme
he
be
greatly
aid
by
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
the
grocer
's
dwelling
,
as
have
be
state
,
be
large
and
commodious
.
<EOS>
It
be
three
story
high
;
and
beneath
the
ground
-
floor
there
be
kitchen
and
extensive
cellar
.
<EOS>
many
of
the
room
be
spacious
,
and
have
curiously
carve
fireplace
,
wall
pannelle
with
fine
brown
oak
,
large
press
,
and
cupboard
.
 
<EOS>
in
the
yard
,
at
the
back
of
the
house
,
there
be
a
pump
,
from
which
excellent
water
be
obtain
.
<EOS>
there
be
likewise
three
large
cistern
,
supply
from
the
New
River
.
<EOS>
not
satisfied
with
this
,
and
anxious
to
obtain
water
in
which
no
infect
body
could
have
lain
,
or
clothe
have
be
wash
,
Bloundel
have
a
large
tank
place
within
the
cellar
,
and
connect
it
by
pipe
with
the
pump
,
he
contrive
an
ingenious
machine
,
by
which
he
could
work
the
latter
from
within
the
house
--
thus
make
sure
of
a
constant
supply
of
water
direct
from
the
spring
.
 
<EOS>
He
next
address
himself
to
the
front
of
the
house
,
where
he
fix
a
pulley
,
with
a
rope
and
hook
attach
to
it
,
to
the
beam
above
one
of
the
small
bay
window
on
the
second
story
.
<EOS>
by
this
means
,
he
could
let
down
a
basket
or
any
other
article
into
the
street
,
or
draw
up
whatever
he
desire
;
and
as
he
propose
use
this
outlet
as
the
sole
mean
of
communication
with
the
external
world
when
his
house
be
closed
,
he
have
a
wooden
shutter
make
in
the
form
of
a
trap
-
door
,
which
he
could
open
and
shut
at
pleasure
.
 
<EOS>
here
it
be
his
intention
to
station
himself
at
certain
hour
of
the
day
,
and
whenever
he
hold
any
communication
below
,
to
flash
off
a
pistol
,
so
that
the
smoke
of
the
powder
may
drive
back
the
air
,
and
purify
any
vapour
that
find
entrance
of
its
noxious
particle
.
 
<EOS>
He
lay
down
to
himself
a
number
of
regulation
,
which
will
be
more
easily
show
and
more
clearly
understand
,
on
arrive
at
the
period
when
his
plan
come
to
be
in
full
operation
.
<EOS>
to
give
an
instance
,
however
--
if
a
letter
should
be
convey
to
him
by
mean
of
the
pulley
,
he
propose
to
steep
it
in
a
solution
of
vinegar
and
sulphur
;
and
when
dry
and
otherwise
fumigate
,
to
read
it
at
a
distance
by
the
help
of
strong
glass
.
 
<EOS>
in
regard
to
provision
,
after
a
careful
calculation
,
he
buy
upwards
of
three
thousand
pound
'
weight
of
hard
sea
-
biscuit
,
similar
to
those
now
term
captain
's
biscuit
,
and
have
them
stow
away
in
hogshead
.
<EOS>
He
next
order
twenty
huge
cask
of
the
fine
flour
,
which
he
have
pack
up
with
the
great
care
,
as
if
for
a
voyage
to
Barbadoes
or
Jamaica
.
<EOS>
as
these
be
bring
in
through
the
yard
an
accident
have
well
-
nigh
occur
which
may
have
prove
fatal
to
him
.
<EOS>
while
superintend
the
labour
of
Leonard
and
Blaize
,
who
be
roll
the
cask
into
the
house
--
have
stow
away
as
many
as
he
conveniently
could
in
the
upper
part
of
the
premise
--
he
descend
to
the
cellar
,
and
,
open
a
door
at
the
foot
of
a
flight
of
step
lead
from
the
yard
,
call
to
them
to
lower
the
remain
barrel
with
rope
below
.
<EOS>
in
the
hurry
,
Blaize
roll
a
cask
towards
the
open
door
,
and
in
another
instant
it
would
have
fall
upon
the
grocer
,
and
perhaps
have
crush
him
,
but
for
the
interposition
of
Leonard
.
<EOS>
Bloundel
make
no
remark
at
the
time
;
but
he
never
forget
the
service
render
him
by
the
apprentice
.
 
<EOS>
to
bake
the
bread
require
an
oven
,
and
he
accordingly
build
one
in
the
garret
,
lay
in
a
large
stock
of
wood
for
fuel
.
<EOS>
neither
do
he
neglect
to
provide
himself
with
two
cask
of
meal
.
 
<EOS>
but
the
most
important
consideration
be
butcher
's
meat
;
and
for
this
purpose
he
go
to
Rotherhithe
,
where
the
plague
have
not
yet
appear
,
and
agree
with
a
butcher
to
kill
him
four
fat
bullock
,
and
pickle
and
barrel
them
as
if
for
sea
store
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
direct
the
man
to
provide
six
large
barrel
of
pickle
pork
,
on
the
same
understanding
.
<EOS>
these
be
land
at
Queenhithe
,
and
bring
up
to
wood
-
street
,
so
that
they
pass
for
newly
-
land
grocery
.
 
<EOS>
Hams
and
bacon
form
part
of
his
own
trade
<EOS>
,
he
write
to
certain
farmer
with
whom
he
be
in
the
habit
of
deal
,
to
send
him
up
an
unlimited
supply
of
flitch
and
gammon
;
and
his
order
be
promptly
and
abundantly
answer
,
he
soon
find
he
have
more
bacon
than
he
could
possibly
consume
.
<EOS>
He
likewise
lay
in
a
good
store
of
tongue
,
hung
beet
,
and
other
dry
meat
.
 
<EOS>
as
to
wine
,
he
already
have
a
tolerable
stock
;
but
he
increase
it
by
half
a
hogshead
of
the
good
canary
he
could
procure
;
two
cask
of
malmsey
,
each
contain
twelve
gallon
;
a
quarter
-
cask
of
Malaga
sack
;
a
runlet
of
muscadine
;
two
small
runlet
of
aqua
vitae
;
twenty
gallon
of
aniseed
water
;
and
two
eight
-
gallon
runlet
of
brandy
.
<EOS>
to
this
he
add
six
hogshead
of
strongly
-
hopped
Kent
ale
,
calculate
for
keeping
,
which
he
place
in
a
cool
cellar
,
together
with
three
hogshead
of
beer
,
for
immediate
use
.
<EOS>
furthermore
,
he
procure
a
variety
of
distil
water
for
medicinal
purpose
,
amongst
which
he
include
a
couple
of
dozen
of
the
then
fashionable
and
costly
preparation
,
denominate
plague
-
water
.
 
<EOS>
as
,
notwithstanding
all
his
precaution
,
it
be
not
impossible
that
some
of
his
household
may
be
attack
by
the
distemper
,
he
take
care
to
provide
proper
remedy
,
and
,
to
Blaize
's
infinite
delight
,
furnish
himself
with
mithridate
,
Venice
treacle
,
diascorium
,
the
pill
rufu

(
oh
!

)
,

,

,

.

,

,

,

.

,

.
 
<EOS>
regulate

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>

eatable
would

,

,

,

,

--
even
then
note

.
<EOS>
several

be

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.

candle

,

;

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

;

,

;

,

,

.

III
.
 
<EOS>
the
QUACK
DOCTORS
.
 
<EOS>
Patience
,
it
may
be
remember
,
have
promise
Blaize
to
give
him
her
earning
to
enable
him
to
procure
a
fresh

of
medicine
,
and
about

week
after
he
have
receive
the
trifling
amount
(
for
he
have
be
so
constantly
employ
by
the
grocer
that
he
have
no
opportunity
of
get
out
before
)
,
he
sally
forth
to
visit
a
neighbouring
apothecary
,
name
Parkhurst
,
from
whom
he
have
be
in
the

of
purchase
drug
,
and
who
occupy
a
small
shop
not

from
the

's
,

.
<EOS>
Parkhurst

,
and
,
without

,

's

--

,

--

,

,

be

see

?
<EOS>
Blaize
shake

,

.
<EOS>
but
be

press

,

be

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
dissuade
!
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
nothing

.
<EOS>
besides
,
Doctor

sanction

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

"

.

.

,

;

,

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,
"
she

,
control

.
<EOS>
"

.

.

,

.

<EOS>
IV
.
 
<EOS>
the
two
WATCHMEN
.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

.

;

.

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
supper

.

,

<EOS>

Amabel
,

,

will
make
another
attempt
to
enter
the
house
,
and
carry
you
off
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!
<EOS>
when
will
he
cease

persecute

?
"
<EOS>
she
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
when

to

,
"
reply

,

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
_
<EOS>
not
_

,

,
"

,
"
and

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

in

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

_

_

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

be

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
nothing
--
nothing
,
"

,

<EOS>
"
that

will

<EOS>
"
something
,

<EOS>

by
aught
relate

!
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

follow

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
rest

,

sleep

,

.
<EOS>
all

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

"

,
"
till

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

have

;

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

;
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Would

<EOS>

_

_

!
<EOS>
I

--
too

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
His

have

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
 
<EOS>
half

,

;

,

have

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

,

.

.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

no
doubt
make

.
<EOS>
Bell
will

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.

"

"

,
"

,

;
"

.

suffer

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
one

notice

<EOS>

<EOS>
everything

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

not
,
however
,
keep
long
in
suspense
.
<EOS>
throw
off
his
wig
,
and
let
his
own
fair
ringlet
fall
over
his
shoulder
,
the
earl
tear
open
his
cassock
,
and
disclose
his
ordinary
rich
attire
.
<EOS>
at
the
same
time
,
his
face
undergo
an
equally
striking
change,--each
feature
resume
its
original
expression
;
and
the
grocer
,
though
he
witness
the
whole
transformation
,
could
scarcely
believe
that
the
same
individual
he
have
recently
behold
stand
before
him
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
now
know
who
I
be
,
Mr.
Bloundel
,
and
what
bring
me
hither
,
"
say
Rochester
,
with
a
haughty
salutation
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
do
,
my
lord
,
"
reply
the
grocer
,
"
and
I
give
you
full
credit
for
your
daring
and
ingenuity
.
<EOS>
after
the
manner
in
which
I
have
be
impose
upon
myself
,
I
can
make
allowance
for
other
.
"
<EOS>
He
then
turn
to
Amabel
,
and
say
,
in
a
severe
tone
,
"
You
be
no
longer
my
daughter
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Father
!
"
<EOS>
she
cry
,
rush
towards
him
and
throw
herself
at
his
foot
,
"
do
not
cast
me
off
for
ever
.
<EOS>
I
be
not
now
to
blame
.
<EOS>
It
be
owe
to
my
determination
to
disclose
all
to
you
that
the
earl
have
thus
reveal
himself
.
<EOS>
I
may
have
deceive
you
further
--
may
have
flee
with
him
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
forgive
her
!
<EOS>
oh
,
forgive
her
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Mrs.
Bloundel--"or
,
if
any
ill
happen
to
her
,
you
will
be
answerable
for
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
be
this
the
truth
,
my
lord
?
"
ask
the
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
bow
stiffly
in
acquiescence
.
 
<EOS>
"
then
you
be
again
my
child
,
"
say
Bloundel
,
raise
her
,
and
press
her
to
his
bosom
.
<EOS>
"
what
be
your
intention
towards
her
?
"
<EOS>
he
continue
,
address
the
earl
.
 
<EOS>
"
They
may
be
readily
surmise
,
"
reply
Rochester
,
with
a
scornful
laugh
.
 
<EOS>
"
Will
you
we
would
her
,
if
I
agree
to
the
union
,
"
ask
Bloundel
,
tremble
with
concentrated
rage
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
look
at
her
lover
as
if
her
life
hang
on
his
answer
.
 
<EOS>
Rochester
affect
not
to
hear
the
question
,
but
,
as
it
be
repeat
still
more
peremptorily
,
he
repeat
carelessly,--"I
will
consider
of
it
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
deceive
!
<EOS>
deceive
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Amabel
,
fall
on
her
mother
's
neck
,
and
burst
into
tear
.
 
<EOS>
"
this
outrage
shall
not
pass
unpunished
,
"
cry
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
and
before
the
earl
could
draw
his
sword
or
offer
any
resistance
,
he
throw
himself
upon
him
,
and
hurl
him
to
the
ground
,
set
his
foot
upon
his
bosom
.
 
<EOS>
"
do
not
kill
him
,
"
shriek
Amabel
,
terrify
by
the
stern
expression
of
her
father
's
countenance
.
 
<EOS>
"
what
be
you
about
to
do
?
"
gasp
Rochester
,
struggle
ineffectually
to
get
free
.
 
<EOS>
"
Bid
Stephen
bring
a
cord
,
"
cry
the
grocer
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
be
not
go
to
hang
him
?
"
<EOS>
inquire
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
 
<EOS>
"
do
as
I
bid
you
,
"
rejoin
her
husband
,
"
and
lose
no
time
.
"
 
<EOS>
as
she
be
about
to
leave
the
room
,
the
door
open
,
and
Doctor
Hodges
enter
,
follow
by
Leonard
and
Stephen
.
 
<EOS>
"
Mercy
on
us
!
<EOS>
what
be
the
matter
?
<EOS>
"
cry
the
former
,
in
astonishment
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
be
just
arrive
in
time
to
prevent
mischief
,
"
reply
Mrs.
Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
pray
interfere
between
them
.
<EOS>
My
husband
will
attend
to
you
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Arise
,
my
lord
,
"
say
Mr.
Bloundel
,
remove
his
foot
from
the
prostrate
nobleman
;
"
you
be
sufficiently
punish
by
be
find
in
this
disgraceful
condition
.
<EOS>
remember
that
your
life
have
be
at
my
disposal
.
"
 
<EOS>
thus
liberate
,
Rochester
spring
to
his
foot
,
and
regard
the
group
with
a
menacing
and
disdainful
look
,
walk
up
to
Amabel
,
and
say
to
her
,
"
You
shall
yet
be
mine
,
"
strode
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
then
march
along
the
passage
,
and
call
to
Pillichody
,
who
instantly
answer
the
summon
.
<EOS>
accompany
by
Hodges
,
the
grocer
follow
them
to
the
shop
,
where
the
bully
not
depart
so
quickly
as
he
desire
,
and
refuse
to
be
more
expeditious
,
he
kick
him
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
this
done
,
and
the
door
fasten
,
he
tarry
only
till
he
have
receive
all
needful
explanation
from
the
friendly
physician
,
and
then
return
to
the
inner
room
,
warmly
greet
Leonard
,
and
congratulate
him
on
his
extraordinary
recovery
from
the
plague
.
 
<EOS>
Happiness
be
thus
once
more
restored
to
every
member
of
the
grocer
's
family
,
except
Amabel
,
who
still
continue
downcast
and
deject
,
and
entreat
permission
to
retire
to
her
own
room
.
<EOS>
a
cheerful
evening
be
then
pass
by
the
other
,
and
the
doctor
do
not
offer
to
take
his
departure
till
the
clock
strike
eleven
.
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
the
last
night
I
shall
spend
here
for
some
month
,
"
he
say
;
"
<EOS>
perhaps
the
last
I
shall
ever
spend
here
,
and
I
have
stay
longer
than
I
intend
,
but
I
do
not
like
to
abridge
my
enjoyment
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
after
shake
hand
cordially
with
the
whole
party
,
he
add
in
an
under
tone
,
as
he
take
leave
of
Leonard
,
"
do
not
forget
Nizza
Macascree
.
"
 
<EOS>
on
the
follow
day
the
grocer
nail
up
the
shutter
,
and
lock
and
bar
the
door
of
his
house
.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
the
THIRD
.
 
<EOS>
JUNE
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
the
IMPRISONED
FAMILY
.
 
<EOS>
the
first
few
day
of
their
confinement
be
pass
by
the
grocer
's
family
in
a
very
uncomfortable
manner
.
<EOS>
no
one
,
except
Mr.
Bloundel
,
appear
reconcile
to
the
plan
,
and
even
he
find
it
more
difficult
of
accomplishment
that
he
have
anticipate
.
<EOS>
the
darkness
of
the
room
,
and
the
want
of
ventilation
cause
by
the
closed
window
and
bar
door
,
give
the
house
the
air
of
a
prison
,
and
occasion
a
sense
of
oppression
almost
intolerable
.
<EOS>
Blaize
declare
it
be
"
bad
than
be
in
Newgate
,
and
that
he
must
take
an
additional
rufu
to
set
right
his
digestion
;
"
while
Patience
affirm
"
that
it
be
like
be
bury
alive
,
and
that
she
would
not
stand
it
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
pay
no
attention
to
their
complaint
,
but
address
himself
seriously
to
the
remedy
.
<EOS>
insist
upon
the
utmost
attention
be
pay
to
cleanliness
,
he
have
an
abundant
supply
of
water
draw
,
with
which
the
floor
of
every
room
and
passage
be
wash
down
daily
.
<EOS>
by
such
mean
the
house
be
keep
cool
and
wholesome
;
and
its
inmate
,
become
habituate
to
the
gloom
,
in
a
great
degree
recover
their
cheerfulness
.
 
<EOS>
the
daily
routine
of
the
establishment
be
as
follow
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
arise
at
dawn
,
and
proceed
to
call
up
the
whole
of
his
family
.
<EOS>
They
then
assemble
in
a
large
room
on
the
second
story
,
where
he
offer
up
thank
that
they
have
be
spare
during
the
night
,
and
pray
for
their
preservation
during
the
day
.
<EOS>
He
next
assign
a
task
to
each
,
and
take
care
to
see
it
afterwards
duly
fulfil
;
<EOS>
well
know
that
constant
employment
be
the
good
way
to
check
repine
and
promote
contentment
.
<EOS>
heretofore
the
servant
have
always
take
their
meal
in
the
kitchen
,
but
now
they
always
sit
down
to
table
with
him
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
no
distinction
at
this
season
,
"
he
say
;
"
all
shall
fare
as
I
fare
,
and
enjoy
the
same
comfort
as
myself
.
<EOS>
and
I
trust
that
my
dwelling
may
be
as
sure
a
refuge
amid
this
pestilential
storm
as
the
ark
of
the
patriarch
prove
when
Heaven
's
vengeance
be
call
forth
in
the
mighty
flood
.
"
 
<EOS>
Their
devotion
end
,
the
whole
party
repair
to
one
of
the
low
room
,
where
a
plentiful
breakfast
be
provide
,
and
of
which
they
all
partook
.
<EOS>
the
business
of
the
day
then
begin
,
and
,
as
have
just
be
observe
,
no
one
be
suffer
to
remain
idle
.
<EOS>
the
young
child
be
allow
to
play
and
exercise
themselves
as
much
as
they
choose
in
the
garret
,
and
Blaize
and
Patience
be
occasionally
invite
to
join
them
.
<EOS>
a
certain
portion
of
the
evening
be
also
devote
to
harmless
recreation
and
amusement
.
<EOS>
the
result
may
be
anticipate
.
<EOS>
no
one
suffer
in
health
,
while
all
improve
in
spirit
.
<EOS>
prayer
,
as
usual
,
conclude
the
day
,
and
the
family
retire
to
rest
at
an
early
hour
.
 
<EOS>
this
system
of
thing
may
appear
sufficiently
monotonous
,
but
it
be
precisely
adapt
to
the
exigency
of
the
case
,
and
produce
a
most
salutary
effect
.
<EOS>
regular
duty
and
regular
employment
be
impose
upon
each
,
and
their
constant
recurrence
,
so
far
from
be
irksome
,
soon
become
agreeable
.
<EOS>
after
a
while
the
whole
family
seem
to
grow
indifferent
to
the
external
world
--
to
live
only
for
each
other
,
and
to
think
only
of
each
other
--
and
to
Leonard
Holt
,
indeed
,
that
house
be
all
the
world
.
<EOS>
those
wall
contain
everything
dear
to
him
,
and
he
would
have
be
quite
content
never
to
leave
them
if
Amabel
have
be
always
near
.
<EOS>
He
make
no
attempt
to
renew
his
suit
--
seldom
or
never
exchange
a
word
with
her
,
and
may
have
be
suppose
to
have
become
wholly
indifferent
to
her
.
<EOS>
but
it
be
not
so
.
<EOS>
His
heart
be
consume
by
the
same
flame
as
before
.
<EOS>
no
longer
,
however
,
a
prey
to
jealousy
--
no
longer
apprehensive
of
the
earl
<EOS>
--
he
feel
so
happy
,
in
comparison
with
what
he
have
be
,
that
he
almost
pray
that
the
term
of
their
imprisonment
may
be
prolong
.
<EOS>
sometimes
the
image
of
Nizza
Macascree
would
intrude
upon
him
,
and
he
think
,
with
a
feeling
akin
to
remorse
,
of
what
she
may
suffer
--
for
he
be
too
well
acquaint
with
the
pang
of
unrequited
love
not
to
sympathise
deeply
with
her
.
<EOS>
as
to
Amabel
,
she
address
herself
assiduously
to
the
task
enjoin
by
her
father
,
and
allow
her
mind
to
dwell
as
little
as
possible
on
the
past
,
but
employ
all
her
spare
time
in
devotional
exercise
.
 
<EOS>
It
will
be
remember
that
the
grocer
have
reserve
a
communication
with
the
street
,
by
mean
of
a
shutter
opening
from
a
small
room
in
the
upper
story
.
<EOS>
hither
he
would
now
frequently
repair
,
and
though
he
do
not
as
yet
think
it
necessary
to
have
recourse
to
all
the
precautionary
measure
he
intend
eventually
to
adopt
--
such
as
flash
a
pistol
when
he
look
forth
--
yet
he
never
open
the
shutter
without
hold
a
phial
of
vinegar
,
or
a
handkerchief
wet
with
the
same
liquid
,
to
his
face
.
 
<EOS>
before
close
his
house
he
have
hire
a
porter
,
who
occupy
the
hutch
at
his
door
,
and
hold
himself
in
readiness
to
execute
any
commission
,
or
perform
any
service
that
may
be
require
.
<EOS>
fresh
vegetable
,
poultry
,
egg
,
butter
,
and
milk
,
be
bring
by
a
higgler
from
the
country
,
and
raise
by
mean
of
a
basket
or
a
can
attach
to
the
pulley
.
<EOS>
Butcher
's
meat
be
fetch
him
from
Newgate
-
market
by
the
porter
.
<EOS>
this
man
,
whose
name
be
Ralph
Dallison
,
have
be
formerly
in
the
employ
of
the
grocer
,
who
,
know
his
character
,
could
place
entire
reliance
on
him
.
<EOS>
Dallison
report
the
progress
of
the
pestilence
daily
,
and
acquaint
him
with
the
increase
amount
of
the
bill
of
mortality
.
<EOS>
several
house
,
he
say
,
be
infect
in
Cheapside
,
and
two
in
Wood
-
street
,
one
of
which
be
but
a
short
distance
from
the
grocer
's
habitation
.
<EOS>
a
watchman
be
station
at
the
door
,
and
the
red
cross
mark
upon
it
,
and
on
the
following
night
the
grocer
hear
the
sound
of
the
doleful
bell
announce
the
approach
of
the
pest
-
cart
.
 
<EOS>
the
weather
still
continue
as
serene
and
beautiful
as
ever
,
but
no
refresh
shower
fall
--
no
soft
and
healthful
breeze
blow
--
and
it
be
now
find
to
be
true
,
what
have
be
prognosticate
--
viz
,
that
with
the
heat
of
summer
the
plague
would
fearfully
increase
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
be
not
incommode
in
the
same
degree
as
his
neighbour
.
<EOS>
by
exclude
the
light
he
exclude
the
heat
,
and
the
care
which
he
take
to
have
his
house
wash
down
keep
it
cool
.
<EOS>
the
middle
of
June
have
arrive
,
and
such
dismal
account
be
now
bring
him
of
the
havoc
occasion
by
the
scourge
,
that
he
would
no
longer
take
in
fresh
provision
,
but
begin
to
open
his
store
.
<EOS>
Dallison
tell
him
that
the
alarm
be
bad
than
ever
--
that
vast
number
be
endeavour
to
leave
the
city
,
but
no
one
could
now
do
so
without
a
certificate
,
which
be
never
grant
if
the
slight
suspicion
be
attach
to
the
party
.
 
<EOS>
"
if
thing
go
on
in
this
way
,
"
say
the
porter
,
"
London
will
soon
be
desert
.
<EOS>
no
business
be
conduct
,
as
it
use
to
be
,
and
everybody
be
view
with
distrust
.
<EOS>
the
preacher
,
who
ought
to
be
the

quit
,
have
leave

,
and
the
Lord
's
day
be
no
longer
observe
.
<EOS>
many
medical
man
even
have
depart
,
declare
their
service
be
no

of

.
<EOS>
all
public

be
suspend
,
and
the
tavern
be
only
open
to
the
profane
and
dissolute
,
who
deride

's
judgment
,
and
declare

have
no
fear
.
<EOS>
robbery
,
murder
,
and
other

,
have
greatly
increase
,
and
the
most

deed
be
now
commit
with
impunity
.
<EOS>
You
have
do
wisely
,
sir
,
in
protect
yourself
against

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
reason
to
be

that

have
do
so
,
"
reply

.
<EOS>
and

close
his

to

what
he
have
just

.
 
<EOS>
and
there
be
abundant

for

.
<EOS>
around

lie
a
great

,
hem

,
as
by

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
no

--

--

,

.
<EOS>

,

address

,
implore

.
 
<EOS>
on
join
his

,
his
grave

and

show

have
be

.
<EOS>
no

,

.
 
<EOS>

one

.
<EOS>
this
be

work

's

.
<EOS>

state

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"
alas
!
<EOS>
no
,

"

I

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
oh

<EOS>

;

;

.
<EOS>
a

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

portion
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

_

_

,

,
"

;
"
it

.
<EOS>
while

be

--

scourge
--

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

;

,

<EOS>

pile
.
<EOS>
ten

other

be

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

"

<EOS>
III
.
 
<EOS>
the

of

.
 
<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

recover
himself
,
and
then
,
motion
him
to
follow
him
,
they
quit

.
 
<EOS>
on
reach
Mr.
Bloundel
's
habitation
,
Leonard
pull
the

in
the

,
and
the

appear

.
 
<EOS>
"
My
daughter
have
not
leave

this

,
"
he
say
,
in

's

,
"
and
I
fear
she
be
much
bad
.
<EOS>
My

be
with

.
<EOS>
It

be

to

see

again
.
"
 
<EOS>

,
Hodges
assent
,
and
be

as

.
<EOS>
He
return
in
about

,
and

convince

that
his

be

.
<EOS>
He
therefore

,
and
they

in

.
 
<EOS>
on
emerge

,

,
"
It

pain

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Her

touch

bad
I
have
see
of

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I

prevail

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
"
<EOS>

,

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!
that

be

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
the

then

,

.
<EOS>
They
be

of

pest
-

,
and

,
hear

,

,
bear

,

-

.
<EOS>
He

,

Bell
,

,

,

,

after

,

.
<EOS>
the

,

be
proceed

,

,

,

-

.
<EOS>

whistle

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

,

.
<EOS>

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
curse

!
<EOS>

?
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
here

,
fear

some

,

beheld

.
<EOS>
His

.
<EOS>
there
,

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

"
 
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

never

,

.
<EOS>
the

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
have

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

-

,

,

,

-

-

,

.
<EOS>
the

which
he
be
about
to
visit
be
about

,

,
and
the
like
number
deep
.
<EOS>
into

the
dead
be

throw
,
without

to

or

,
generally
strip
of
their

,
and
cover

of

and

.
 
<EOS>
the
sun
be
set
as
Leonard
walk
towards
this
dismal
place
,
and
he
think
he
have
never
witness
so
magnificent
a

.
<EOS>
indeed
,
it
be

that
at
this
fatal
season
the

be
unusually

.
<EOS>
the

orb
sink

behind
Saint
Paul
's
,
which
form

in
the
view
from

field
,
and
throw

,

,
and
the
two
less

flank

,
into

.
<EOS>

gaze
at

mighty
fabric
,
which
seem

to
twice

by
this
light
,
and

whether

that

ever

,
as
predict

Eagle
.
 
<EOS>
long

have

,

be

with

,
and

of

be

.
<EOS>
the

be
intense
,
and

,

,

--

,

be

,

--

,

,

towards

.
<EOS>
after

he
arise
,
and

the

-

.
<EOS>
the

be
trample
down
near
it
,
and
there
be
mark

-

upon

.
<EOS>
great

of

,
throw

,

.
<EOS>
hold

steep
in
vinegar
to
his
face
,
Leonard
venture
to
the
brink
of
the
pit
.
<EOS>
but

could
not

the

arise

.
<EOS>
It
be
more

fill

;

through

many

,

.
<EOS>

--

,

,

linger

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

--

--

.
<EOS>

turn

,

.
<EOS>
It
be
the

,
charge

.
 
<EOS>
the

that

,

,

,

be

.
 
<EOS>
shovel

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.

one

its
former
keeper
who
still
linger
about
the
place
--
and
prepare
to
descend
to
Saint
Faith
's
.
<EOS>
Leonard
follow
as
near
as
he
could
without
expose
himself
,
and
,
on
gain
the
subterranean
church
,
easily
contrive
to
screen
himself
behind
the
ponderous
rank
of
pillar
.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
they
have
reach
the
door
of
the
charnel
It
be
closed
;
but
Rochester
knock
against
it
,
and
Chowles
presently
appear
.
<EOS>
He
seem
greatly
surprised
at
see
the
earl
,
nor
be
the
latter
less
astonished
when
he
learn
that
Parravicin
be
within
the
vault
.
<EOS>
He
desire
to
be
show
to
his
friend
,
and
Chowles
usher
him
into
the
crypt
.
<EOS>
Leonard
would
have
follow
them
;
but
as
Etherege
and
the
other
decline
enter
the
charnel
,
and
remain
at
the
door
,
he
could
not
do
so
.
 
<EOS>
shortly
after
this
the
sick
man
be
bring
out
,
stretch
upon
a
pallet
,
bear
by
Chowles
and
Judith
;
and
the
party
proceed
slowly
,
and
occasionally
relieve
each
other
,
to
the
great
western
entrance
,
where
a
coach
be
procure
by
Pillichody
,
Parravicin
be
place
within
it
,
with
Judith
and
Chowles
;
and
order
be
give
in

under
-
tone
to
the
driver
,
he
depart
.
<EOS>
the
other
then
proceed
towards
Ludgate
,
while
Leonard
,
again
disappoint
,
retrace
his
step
to
wood
-
street
.

<EOS>
V.
 
HOW
SAINT
PATHOS
be
use
as
a
PEST
-
HOUSE
.
 
<EOS>
the
distemper
have
by
this
time
increase
to
such
a
frightful
extent
,
that
the
pest
-
house
be
find
wholly
inadequate
to
contain
the
number
of
sick
person
send
to
them
,
it
be
resolve
by
the
civic
authority
,
who
have
obtain
the
sanction
of
the
Dean
and
Chapter
of
Saint
Paul
's
for
that
purpose
,
to
convert
the
cathedral
into
a
receptacle
for
the
infect
.
<EOS>
accordingly
,
a
meeting
be
hold
in
the
Convocation
House
to
make
final
arrangement
.
<EOS>
It
be
attend
by
Sir
John
Lawrence
,
the
Lord
Mayor
;
by
Sir
George
Waterman
,
and
Sir
Charles
Doe
,
sheriff
;
by
Doctor
Sheldon
,
Archbishop
of
Canterbury
;
by
the
Duke
of
Albemarle
,
the
Earl
of
Craven
,
and
,
a
few
other
zealous
and
humane
person
.
<EOS>
several
member
of
the
College
of
Physicians
be
likewise
present
,
and
,
amongst
other
,
Doctor
Hodges
;
and
the
expediency
of
the
measure
be
fully
agree
upon
,
it
be
determined
to
carry
it
into
immediate
execution
.
 
<EOS>
the
cloister
surround
the
Convocation
House
be
crowd
with
sick
person
,
draw
thither
by
the
rumour
of
what
be
go
forward
;
and
when
the
meeting
adjourn
to
the
cathedral
,
these
unfortunate
being
follow
them
,
and
be
with
some
difficulty
keep
aloof
from
the
uninfected
by
the
attendant
.
<EOS>
a
very
earnest
and
touching
address
be
next
pronounce
by
the
archbishop
.
<EOS>
call
upon
his
hearer
to
look
upon
themselves
as
already
dead
to
the
world,--to
regard
the
present
visitation
as
a
just
punishment
of
their
sin
,
and
to
rejoice
that
their
suffering
would
be
so
soon
terminate
,
when
,
if
they
sincerely
and
heartily
repent
,
they
would
at
once
be
transport
from
the
depth
of
wretchedness
and
misery
to
region
of
unfade
bliss
;
he
conclude
by
state
that
he
,
and
all
those
around
him
,
be
prepare
to
devote
themselves
,
without
regard
to
their
own
safety
,
to
the
preservation
of
their
fellow
-
citizen
,
and
that
they
would
leave
nothing
undone
to
stop
the
ravage
of
the
devour
scourge
.
 
<EOS>
It
chance
that
Leonard
Holt
be
present
on
this
occasion
,
and
as
he
listen
to
the
eloquent
discourse
of
the
archbishop
,
and
gaze
at
the
group
around
him
,
all
equally
zealous
in
the
good
cause
,
and
equally
regardless
of
themselves
,
he
could
not
but
indulge
a
hope
that
their
exertion
may
be
crown
with
success
.
<EOS>
It
be
indeed
a
touching
sight
to
see
the
melancholy
congregation
to
whom
his
address
be
deliver
--
many
,
nay
most
of
whom
be
on
the
verge
of
dissolution;--and
<EOS>
Leonard
Holt
be
so
move
by
the
almost
apostolic
fervour
of
the
prelate
,
<EOS>
that
,
but
for
the
thought
of
Amabel
,
he
may
have
follow
the
example
of
several
of
the
auditor
,
and
devote
himself
altogether
to
the
service
of
the
sick
.
 
<EOS>
His
discourse
conclude
,
the
archbishop
and
most
of
his
companion
quit
the
cathedral
.
<EOS>
hodge
,
however
,
and
three
of
the
physician
,
remain

to
superintend

necessary
preparation
.
<EOS>
shortly

,
a
large
number
of
pallet
be
bring
in
,
and
range
along
the
nave
and
aisle
at
short

from
each
other
;
and
,
before
night
,
the
interior
of
the

present

of
an
hospital
.
<EOS>
act
under
the
direction
of
Doctor
Hodges
,
Leonard
Holt
lend
his

in
arrange

,
in
cover

with
bedding
and

,
and
in
execute
any
other

require
of
him
.
<EOS>
a
sufficient
number
of
chirurgeon
and
nurse
be
then
send
for
,
and
such
be
the
expedition
use
,
that
on
that
very
night
most
of
the
pallet
be
occupy
.
<EOS>
thus
the
cathedral
undergo
another
afflict
change
.
<EOS>
a
blight
have
come
over
it
,
mildew
its
holy
wall
,
and
taint
and
pollute
its
altar
.
<EOS>
Its

,
once
trodden
by
grave
and
reverend

,
and
subsequently
haunt
by
ruffler
,
bully
,
and
other
worthless
character
,
be
now
fill
with
miserable
wretch
,
stricken
with
a

and

.
<EOS>
Its
chapel
and
shrine
formerly
adorn
with

and

,
but
strip
of
them
at
time
when
they
be
look
upon
as
idolatrous
and

,
be
now
occupy
by
nurse
,

,
and
their
attendant
;
while
every
niche
and
corner
be
fill
with
surgical
implement
,
phial
,
drug
,
poultice
,
foul

,
and
linen
.
 
<EOS>
in
less
than
a
week
after
it
have
be
convert
into
a
pest
-
house
,
the
cathedral
be
crowd
to
overflow
.
<EOS>
upwards
of
three
hundred
pallet
be
set
up
in
the
nave
,
in
the
aisle
,
in
the
transept
,
and
in
the
choir
,
and
even
in
the
chapel
.
<EOS>
but
these
prove
insufficient
,
many
poor
wretch
who
be
bring
thither
be
place
on
the
cold
flag
,
and
protect
only
by
a
single
blanket
.
<EOS>
at
night
the
scene
be
really
terrific
.
<EOS>
the
imperfect
light
borne
by
the
attendant
fall
on
the
couch
,
and
reveal
the
livid
countenance
of
their
occupant
;
while
the
vaulted
roof
rang
with
shriek
and
groan
<EOS>
so
horrible
and
heart
-
pierce
as
to
be
scarcely
endure
,
except
by
those
whose
nerve
be
firmly

,
or
have

blunt
by
their
constant
recurrence
.
<EOS>
at
such
time
,
too
,
some
unhappy
creature
,
frenzy
by
agony
,
would
burst
from
his
couch
,
and
rend
the
air
with

cry
,
until
overtaken
and
overpower
by
his
attendant
.
<EOS>
on
one

,

happen
that
a

,
who
have
be
thus
catch
,
break

,
and
dart
through
a
door
lead
to
the
stone

in
the
northern
transept
gain
the
ambulatory
,
and
be
closely
follow
,
to
escape

,
spring
through
one
of
the
arched
opening
,
and
fall
from
a

of
near

foot
,
be
dash
in
piece
on

beneath
.
 
<EOS>
a
walk
through
this
mighty
lazar
-
house
would
have
furnish
a
wholesome
lesson
to
the
most
reckless
observer
.
<EOS>
It
seem
to
contain
all
the
sick
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
and
yet

be
not
so
.
<EOS>
hundred
be
expire
in
their
own

,
and
the
other
pest
-
house
continue

as
before
.
<EOS>
still
,
as

far
great
number
of

infect
be
here

,
and
could
be
see

,

picture
be

more

.
<EOS>
every

of
the
cathedral
be
occupy
.
<EOS>
those

could
not

inside

crouch

on
rug

,
and

as

pass

.
<EOS>
want

room
also
drive
other
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
here

be
,
if

,

.
<EOS>
in

it
be
find

obtain

,
and
consequently

,
unable
to

,
acquire

,
that
it
be
almost

to

.
<EOS>
after

,
few
of
the
nurse
and

would

;
and
to
take
a
patient
to
Saint
Faith
's
be
consider
tantamount

.
 
<EOS>
whether
Judith
Malmayns
have
succeed

Sir

,

.
<EOS>
soon

be

-

she

,

,

,

appoint

.
<EOS>
It

be

.
<EOS>
such

of
obtain

,
that
little

be
leave
,
and
the

be
all
of
questionable
character
<EOS>
,

be
only

bad
than

,

.
<EOS>
and

;
for

's
be

,

,
and
quit

.
<EOS>
a

be

at

,

of
body
be
nightly

.
<EOS>
but

be
soon
fill
,
and

be

to

,

,
to
Finsbury
Fields
,
and

near

.
<EOS>
when
not
engage
in
this
revolt
employment
,
Chowles
take
up

in

,
where
,
in

of
his

to
the

,

indulge

in

.
<EOS>
He
and

have
amass
,

or

,
a

of

,
and
frequently
plan
how

when

cease
.
<EOS>
Their

be
carefully

in
a
cell
in

of
the
secret
passage
with
which

be

,
lead
from
Saint
Faith
's
to
the
upper
structure
.
 
<EOS>
one
night
,
on
his
return
from
Finsbury
Fields
,
as
Chowles
be
seat
in

,
with

,

-

of

,
he
be

by

of
Judith
,
who
,

,
seize

by

,
and
almost

before

.
 
<EOS>
"
what
be
the
matter?--would
you
strangle
me
,
you
murderous

?
"
he
cry
.
 
<EOS>
"
ay
,
that
I
would
,
"
reply
Judith
,
prepare
to
renew
the
attack
.
 
<EOS>
"
stand
off
!
"
rejoin
Chowles
,
spring
back
,
and
snatch
up
a

,
"
or
I
will
dash
out
your
brain
.
<EOS>
be
you
mad
?
"
<EOS>
he
continue
,
gaze
fearfully
at
her
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
angry
enough
to
make
me
so
,
"
she
reply
,
shake
her
clenched
fist
at
him
.
"
<EOS>
but
I
will
be
revenge
--
revenge
,
I
tell

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
revenge
!
"
<EOS>
cry
Chowles
,
in
astonishment--"for
what
!
<EOS>
what
have
I
do
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
do
well
to
affect

,
"
rejoin
Judith
,
"
but
you
can
not
deceive
me
.
<EOS>
no
one
<EOS>
but
you
can
have
do
it
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
done
what
!
"
exclaim
Chowles
,
in
increase
astonishment
.
"
<EOS>
have
our
hoard
be
discover
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
ay
,
and
be
carry
off
--
by
you
--
you
!
"
<EOS>
scream
Judith
,
with
a
look
worthy
of
a

.
 
<EOS>
"
by
my
soul
,
you
be
wrong
,
"
cry

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
never
touch
it,--never
even

hiding
-
place
,
except
in

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
liar
!
"
return

,
"
the
whole
hoard
be
gone;--the
plunder
I
obtain
in
Newgate,--the
Earl
of
Rochester
's

the
ring
,

,
and
rich
apparel
<EOS>
I
have
pick
up
since,--everything
<EOS>
be
gone;--and
who
<EOS>
but
you
can
be
the
robber
?
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
be
difficult
to
say
,
"
rejoin

.
"
<EOS>
but
I

to

,
you

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"
reply

,
"

be

.
<EOS>
if

,
I
will

the

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
let
us
go
to
the
hiding
-
place
,
"
reply

,
whose
uneasiness
be
not
diminish
by
the

.
<EOS>
"
You
may
be
mistaken
,
and
I
hope
you
be
.
"
 
<EOS>
though
he
utter
the
latter
part
of

with
seem
confidence
,
his
heart
misgave
him
.
<EOS>
to

,
he

,
and
pass
through

secret
door
,
hurry

passage
.
<EOS>
He
be
about
to
open
the
cell
,

the

.
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

river
,
and
as
she
turn
on
his
entrance
,
Leonard
perceive
that
her
eye
be
fill
with

.
<EOS>
blush

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
She

,

,
have

see

be

,

.
<EOS>
comparison

,

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

"

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.

.

"

fill

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

DEPARTURE
.
 
<EOS>

man
lead

,

,

.

<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
He

--

Eagle
on

.
<EOS>

;

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
so

itself

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

VIII
.
 
<EOS>
ASHDOWN
LODGE
.
 
<EOS>
erect
by
Inigo
Jones
,
and
still
continue
in
precisely
the
same
state
as
at
the
period
of
this
history
,
Ashdown
Lodge
be
a
large
square
edifice
,
build
in
the
formal
french
taste
of
the
seventeenth
century
,
with
immense
casement
,
give
it
the
appearance
of
be
all
glass
,
a
high
roof
light
by
dormer
windows
,
terminate
at

,

,

.
<EOS>
the

open

square
gallery
defend
by

,
and
overlook
the
umbrageous
masse
and
lovely
hill
around

.
<EOS>
the
house
,
as
have
be
state
,
be
approach
by
four

,
the
timber
constitute
which
,
be
,
of
course
,
much
fine
now
than
at
the
period
under
consideration
,
and
possess
a

old

,

.
<EOS>
the
room
be
lofty

,
and
there
be
a

,

.
<EOS>
among

,

,
daughter

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
be

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
for
hot

reek

,

,

,

--
for

--

--

--
<EOS>

--

--
for

,

green

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
often

,

have

,

!
 
<EOS>
but

he

from
have

city

,

lest

.
<EOS>

,

;

meal,--for

,

,

,

Pillichody
,
meanwhile
,
have
retire
with
a
discomfited
air
into
a
corner
,
where
he
seat
himself
on
a
stool
,
and
eye
the
porter
askance
,
as
if
meditate
some
terrible
retaliation
.
<EOS>
secretly
apprehensive
of
this
,
and
think
it
become
to
act
with
generosity
towards
his
foe
,
Blaize
march
up
to
him
,
and
extend
his
hand
in
token
of

.
<EOS>
to
the
surprise
of
all
,
Pillichody
do
not
reject
his
overture
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
great
regard
for
you
,
friend
Blaize
,
"
he
say
,
"
otherwise
I
should
never
rest
till
I
have
be
repay
with
terrible
interest
for
the
indignity
I
have
endure
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
heed
them
not
,
"
reply
Blaize
.
<EOS>
"
You
must
make
allowance
for
the
jealous
feeling
you
excited
.
<EOS>
I
love
Patience
well
than
my
life
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
since
you
put
it
in
that
light
,
"
rejoin
Pillichody
,
"
I
be
willing
to
overlook
the
offence
.
<EOS>
snake
and
scorpion
!
<EOS>
no
man
can
be
a
great
martyr
to
jealousy
than
myself
.
<EOS>
I
kill
three
of

most
intimate
friend
for
merely

ogle
the
widow
of
watling
-

,
who
would
have
be
mine
,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
do
not

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
It

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
nay
,

.
<EOS>
I
entirely

,
and
be

in

.
"
 
<EOS>
readily

,
Blaize
obtain

from

,

,

<EOS>

?
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

.

,

.

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
motion

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
They

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
"

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
BOOK
the
FOURTH
.
 
<EOS>
SEPTEMBER
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
the
PLAGUE
<EOS>
at
its
HEIGHT
.
 
<EOS>
Amabel
's
departure
for
Berkshire
cause
no
change
in
her
father
's
mode
of
life
.
<EOS>
everything
proceed
as
before
within
his
quiet
dwelling
;
and
,
except
that
the
family
be
diminish

number
,
all
appear

same
.
<EOS>
It
be
true

want
the
interest
,
and
indeed
the
occupation
,
afford
them
by
the
gentle
invalid
,
but
in
other

,
no

be

.
<EOS>
devotional

,
meal
,
the

of
the
house
,
and

,
fill

,

never

.
<EOS>
the

prove

Bloundel
's

.
<EOS>
while

continue
weekly
to
extend

throughout
the
city
,
it
never
cross

;
and
,
except
suffer
in

from
scorbutic

,
occasion
by

salt

to

be

,

,
provide

,
prove

,
all

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

do

;

.
<EOS>

,

become

,

increase

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
in

,

pass

.
<EOS>

other

be

.
<EOS>

July

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
not

suffocate

,

,

-

-

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
number

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
below

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

of

.
 
<EOS>
August
have

,
but

know

.
<EOS>

,

manifestly

.
<EOS>

,

!
 
<EOS>
but
,

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

;

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
to

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Crossing

Bridge
<EOS>
,

,

<EOS>

,

,

"
 
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
pass

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

,
"

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
poor

!
<EOS>
she

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

'

'

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

its

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
'
the
street
shall
be
cover
with
grass
,
and
the
living
shall
not
be
able
to
bury
their
dead,'--so
<EOS>
it
run
,
"
say
Rainbird
.
<EOS>
"
and
it
have
come
to
pass
.
<EOS>
not
a
carriage
of
any
description
,
save
the
dead
-
cart
,
be
to

see
in
the

of

,
which
be
now
as
green

without
her

,
and

grave
itself
.
<EOS>
terrible
time
,
as
I
say
before
--
terrible
time
!
<EOS>
the
dead
be
rot
in
heap
in

,
in

,

,

no

.
<EOS>
what
will

?
<EOS>
what

?
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"
reply

,
"
unless

to

.
<EOS>
and
something
whisper
in

that

be
now

bad
.
<EOS>
the

can
not

without
work

;
and
deeply

sin
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

dare

,
"

,
"
though

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
chowle

he
bury

have

,
and
yet

do

-

.
<EOS>
He
be

Chowles
.
<EOS>

there

,

be

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

amass

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
true
,
"

.
"
<EOS>

to
the

,

,

,
of

in

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
in

's
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
no
--

,

,

perish
,

,

,
"

.
"
<EOS>

have
fill

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

have

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
the

have
,

,

;

,

;

,

of

.
<EOS>
other

,

would

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
Rainbird

,

fish

.
<EOS>
ascend

,

,

,

.

"

.

<EOS>
"

"

be

.
<EOS>
wo
to
london!--wo!--wo
!
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
echo

,

.
<EOS>
It
have

that

be

;

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
to

--

-

--

.
<EOS>
on

have

.
<EOS>
no

be

,

.
<EOS>
hush

,

hundred

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
on

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

's

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

!

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

"

:
"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

,

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
these

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

as

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
no

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She
note

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,
must

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

!
"

,

.
"
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

"
that

me

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
V.
 
<EOS>
the
MARRIAGE
and
its

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

herself
,

,

.
<EOS>
see

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

,

be

.
 
<EOS>

Holt
,

,

,

.
<EOS>
have

,

,

.
<EOS>
fully

.
 
<EOS>

,
"

,

"

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!

with

,
and
complete

good
work
you
have
begin
?
"
 
<EOS>
Amabel

,

,

.
<EOS>
an

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

then
ask
where
the
house
in
which
she
have
die
be
situate
,
rush
out
of
the
room
,
and
make

way
,
he
know
not
<EOS>
how
,
into
the
street
.
<EOS>
His
brain
seem
on
fire
,
and
he
run
so

that

foot
appear

to

.
<EOS>
a

bring

to

.
<EOS>
He

,
and
turn

on

,
have

,

.
<EOS>

-

be

,

two
man
,

,
from

,
burier
of
the
dead
,
issue

.
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>
a

horror
root
Leonard
to
the

stand
.
<EOS>
He
could
neither

nor

.
 
<EOS>
the

proceed

,

be
mark

.
<EOS>
before

stand
the
dead
-
cart
,
partly

.
<EOS>
the

,

do

.
<EOS>
Leonard
,

,

not

the
body

.
<EOS>
the

be

,

over

,
and

wheel

.
 
<EOS>
on
reach
the
door
of
the

,

near

a

which

.
<EOS>
at

,
Chowles
,

,

.
<EOS>
"

get
,
Jonas
?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
not
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
We
enter
yon

house
,

stand

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
so

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

body
it

.
"
 
<EOS>
as

,

hold

,
and

,
throw

light
full
upon

.
<EOS>
the
feature
be
pale
as
marble
;
calm
in

,

like

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
"

,

,

's

,
Amabel,--somewhile

!
"

.
 
<EOS>
"
It

,

!
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

--

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

,
"

--

<EOS>

--

.

"

,

.
"
 
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
the
FIFTH
.
 
<EOS>
DECEMBER
,
1665
.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
the
decline
of
the
PLAGUE
.
 
<EOS>
More
than
two
month
must
be
pass
over
in
silence
.
<EOS>
during
that
time
,
the
pestilence
have
so
greatly
abate
as
no
longer
to
occasion
alarm
to
those
who
have
escape
its
ravage
.
<EOS>
It
have
be
mention
that
the
distemper
arrive
at
its
height
about
the
10th
of
September
,
and
though
for
the
two
follow
week
the
decline
be
scarcely
perceptible
,
yet
it
have
already
commence
.
<EOS>
on
the
last
week
in
that
fatal
month
,
when
all
hope
have
be
abandon
,
the
bill
of
mortality
suddenly
decrease
in
number
to
one
thousand
eight
hundred
and
thirty
-
four
.
<EOS>
and
this
fortunate
change
could
not
be
attribute
to
the
want
of
material
to
act
upon
,
for
the
sick
continue
as
numerous
as
before
,
while
the
death
be
less
frequent
.
<EOS>
in
the
next
week
there
be
a
further
decrease
of
six
hundred
;
in
the
next
after
that
of
six
hundred
;
and
so
on
till
the
end
of
October
,
when
,
the
cold
weather
set
in
,
the
amount
be
reduce
to
nearly
one
thousand
.
 
<EOS>
at
first
,
when
the
distemper
begin
to
lose
somewhat
of
its
malignancy
,
a
few
scared
individual
appear
in
the
street
,
but
carefully
shun
each
other
.
<EOS>
in
a
few
day
,
however
,
considerable
number
join
them
,
and
for
the
first
time
for
nearly
three
month
there
be
something
like
life
abroad
.
<EOS>
It
be
astonish
how
soon
hope
and
confidence
be
revive
.
<EOS>
now
that
it
could
no
longer
be
doubt
that
the
plague
be
on
the
decline
,
it
seem
as
if
a
miracle
have
be
perform
in
favour
of
the
city
.
<EOS>
house
be
open
--
shopkeeper
resume
their
business
--
and
it
be
a
marvel
to
every
one
that
so
many
person
be
leave
alive
.
<EOS>
dejection
and
despair
of
the
dark
kind
be
succeed
by
frenzied
delight
,
and
no
bind
be
put
to
the
public
satisfaction
.
<EOS>
stranger
stop
each
other
in
the
street
,
and
converse
together
like
old
friend
.
<EOS>
the
bell
,
that
have
grow
hoarse
with
tolling
funeral
,
be
now
crack
with
joyous
peal
.
<EOS>
the
general
joy
extend
even
to
the
sick
,
and
many
,
buoy
up
by
hope
,
recover
,
when
in
the
former
season
of
despondency
they
would
inevitably
have
perish
.
<EOS>
all
fear
of
the
plague
seem
to
vanish
with
the
fly
disorder
.
<EOS>
those
who
be
scarcely
out
of
danger
join
in
the
throng
,
and
it
be
no
uncommon
sight
to
see
man
with
bandage
round
their
neck
,
or
support
by
stave
and
crutch
,
shake
hand
with
their
friend
,
and
even
embrace
them
.
 
<EOS>
the
consequence
of
this
incautious
conduct
may
be
easily
foresee
.
<EOS>
the
plague
have
receive
too
severe
a
check
to
burst
forth
anew
;
but
it
spread
further
than
it
otherwise
would
have
do
,
and
attack
many
person
,
who
but
for
their
own
imprudence
would
have
escape
.
<EOS>
amongst
other
,
a
barber
in
Saint
Martin's
-
le
-
Grand
,
who
have
flee
into
the
country
in
August
,
return
to
his
shop
in
the
middle
of
October
,
and
,
catch
the
disorder
from
one
of
his
customer
,
perish
with
the
whole
of
his
family
.
 
<EOS>
but
these
,
and
several
other
equally
fatal
instance
,
produce
no
effect
on
the
multitude
.
<EOS>
fully
persuade
that
the
virulence
of
the
disorder
be
exhaust
--
as
,
indeed
,
appear
to
be
the
case
--
they
give
free
scope
to
their
satisfaction
,
which
be
great
than
be
ever
experience
by
the
inhabitant
of
a
besiege
city
reduce
by
famine
to
the
last
strait
of
despair
,
and
suddenly
restore
to
freedom
and
plenty
.
<EOS>
the
more
pious
part
of
the
community
throng
to
the

,
from
which
they
have
be
so
long

,
and
return
thank
for
their
unexpected

.
<EOS>
other
,
who
have
be
terrify
into
seriousness
and

,
speedily
forget
their
former
terror
,
and
resume
their
old
habit
.
<EOS>
profaneness
and
debauchery
again
prevail
,
and
the
tavern
be
as
well
fill
as
the
church
.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
continue
his
midnight
course
through
the
street
;
but
he
could
no
longer
find
an
audience
as
before
.
<EOS>
those
who
listen
to
him
only
laugh
at
his
denunciation
of
a
new
judgment
,
and
tell
him
his
preaching
and
prophesying
be
now
completely
out
of
date
.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
number
of
those
who
have
quit
London
have
return
to
it
,
the
street
begin
to
resume
their
wonte
appearance
.
<EOS>
the
utmost
care
be
take
by
the
authority
to
cleanse
and
purify
the
house
,
in
order
to
remove
all
chance
of
keep
alive
the
infection
.
<EOS>
every
room
in
every
habitation
where
a
person
have
die
of
the
plague
--
and
there
be
few
that
have
escape
the
visitation
--
be
order
to
be
whitewash
,
and
the
strong

be
employ
to
remove
the
pestilential

.
<EOS>
brimstone
,
resin
,
and
pitch
be
burn
in
the
house
of
the
poor
;
benjamin
,

,
and
other

in

of

;
while
vast

of

be
consume
in
create

to

.
<EOS>
large
and
constant
fire
be
keep
in
all
the
house
,
and
several
be
burn
down
in

of

.
 
<EOS>
all
good
,
clothe
,
and

,
capable
of
harbour
infection
,
be

be

,

in

Fields
and

,
into
which
many
hundred
cart
-
load
of

be
throw
.
<EOS>
the
whole
of
Chowles
's
hoard
,
except

,

manage
,

Judith
's

,

Saint
Faith
's
,
be
take
from

house
in

-
lane
,
and
cast
into

fire
.
 
<EOS>
the
cathedral
be
one
of
the
first
place
order
to
be
purify
.
<EOS>
the
pallet
of
the
sick
be
remove
and
burn
,
and
all
the
stain
and
impurity
with
which
its
floor
and
column
be
pollute
be
cleanse
.
<EOS>
nothing
be
leave
untried
to
free
it
from
infection
.
<EOS>
It
be
wash
throughout
with
vinegar
,
fumigate
with
the
strong
scent
,
and
several
large
barrel
of
pitch
be
set
fire
to
in
the
aisle
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
It
shall
undergo
another
species
of
purification
,
"
say
Solomon
Eagle
,
who
be
present
during
these
proceeding
;
"
one
that
shall
search
every
nook
within
it
--
shall
embrace
all
those
column
,
and
pierce
every
crack
and

in
those
sculptured
ornament
;
and
then
,
and
not
till
then
,
will
it
be
thoroughly
cleanse
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
during
all
this
time
the
grocer
have
not
open
his
dwelling
.
<EOS>
the
wisdom
of
this
plan
be
now
make
fully
apparent
.
<EOS>
the
plague
be
decline
fast
,
and
not
an
inmate
of
his
house
have
be
attack
by
it
.
<EOS>
soon
after
the
melancholy
occurrence
,
he
have
be
inform
by
Doctor
Hodges
of
Amabel
's
death
;
but

conceal
from
him
the

circumstance
under
which

occur
.
<EOS>
It
require
all
Mr.
Bloundel
's
fortitude
to
support
him
under
the
shock
of
this
intelligence
,
and
he
do
not
communicate
the
afflict
tiding
to
his
wife
until
he
have
prepare
her
for
their

.
<EOS>
but
she
bear
them
better
than
he
have
anticipate
;
and
though
she
mourn
her
daughter
deeply
and

,
she
appear

resign
to
the
loss
.
<EOS>
sorrow
pervade
the
whole
household
for
some
week
;
and
the
grocer
,
who
never
relax
his
system
,
shroud
his
suffering
under
the
appearance
of
additional
austerity
of
manner
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
be
a
great
consolation
to
him
to
see
Leonard
Holt
;
but
the
apprentice
have
disappear
;
and
even
Doctor
Hodges
could
give
no
account
of
him
.
 
<EOS>
one
night
,
in
the
middle
of
November
,
Mr.
Bloundel
signify
to
his
wife
his
intention
of
go
forth
,
early
on
the
follow
morning
,
to
satisfy
himself
that
the
plague
be
really
abating
.
<EOS>
accordingly
,
after
he
have
finish
his
devotion
,
and
break
his
fast
,
he
put
his
design
into
execution
.
<EOS>
His
first
act
,
after
lock
the
door
behind
him
,
which
he
do
as

measure
of

,
be
to
fall
on
his

and
offer
up
prayer
to
Heaven
for
his
signal
preservation
.
<EOS>
He
then
arise
,
and
,
step
into
the
middle
of
the
street
,
gaze
at
the
habitation
which
have
form
his
prison
and
refuge
for
nearly
six
month
.
<EOS>
there
it
be
,
with
its
shutter
close
and
bar
--
a
secure
asylum
,
with
all
alive
within
it
,
while
every
other
dwelling
in
the
street
be
desolate
.
 
<EOS>
the
grocer
's
sensation
be
novel
and
extraordinary
.
<EOS>
His
first
impulse
be
to
enjoy
his
newly
-
recover
freedom
,
and
to
put
himself
into
active
motion
.
<EOS>
but
he
check
the
feeling
as
sinful
,
and
proceed
along
the
street
at
a
slow
pace
.
<EOS>
He
do
not
meet
a
single
person
,
until
he
reach
Cheapside
,
where
he
find
matter
completely
change
.
<EOS>
several
shop
be
already
open
,
and
there
be
a
few
cart
and
other
vehicle
track
their
way
through
the
broad
and
yet
grass
-
grow
street
.
<EOS>
It
be
a
clear
,
frosty
morning
,
and
there
be
a
healthful
feel
in
the
bracing
atmosphere
that
produce
an

He
remain
for
some
time
in
the
deep
affliction
,
and
be
at
last
rouse
by
.
<EOS>
a
hand
lay
upon
his
shoulder
,
and
,
raise
himself
,
beheld
Thirlby
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
must
be
you
,
"
say
the
new
comer
,
in
accent
of
the
deep
commiseration
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
be
visit
yonder
plague
-
pit
for
the
same
melancholy
purpose
as
yourself,--to
mourn
over
my
lose
child
.
<EOS>
I
have
be
in
search
of
you
,
and
have
much
to
say
to
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
meet
me
in
this
place
at
midnight
tomorrow
?
<EOS>
"
Leonard
signify
his
assent
.
 
<EOS>
"
I
be
in
danger
,
"
pursue
Thirlby
,
"
for
,
by
some
mean
,
the
secret
of
my
existence
have
be
make
know
,
and
the
officer
of
justice
be
in
pursuit
of
me
.
<EOS>
I
suspect
that
Judith
Malmayns
be
my
betrayer
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
fail
me
?
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
,
"
return
Leonard
.
<EOS>
upon
this
,
Thirlby
hurry
away
,
and
leap
a
hedge
,
disappear
from
view
.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
slowly
and
sorrowfully
return
to
wood
-
street
.
<EOS>
on
arrive
there
,
he
assure
his
master
that
he
may
with
entire
safety
open
his
house
,
as
he
propose
,
on
the
morrow
;
and
Doctor
Hodges
,
who
visit
the
grocer
the
same
evening
,
confirm
the
opinion
.
<EOS>
early
,
therefore
,
the
next
morning
,
Mr.
Bloundel
summon
his
family
to
prayer
;
and
after
pour
forth
his
supplication
with
peculiar
fervour
and
solemnity
,
he
go
,
accompany
by
them
all
,
and
throw
open
the
street
-
door
.
<EOS>
again
,
kneel
down
at
the
threshold
,
he
pray
fervently
,
as
before
.
<EOS>
He
then
proceed
to
remove
the
bar
and
shutter
from
the
window
.
<EOS>
the
transition
from
gloom
and
darkness
to
bright
daylight
be
almost
overpower
.
<EOS>
for
the
first
time
for
six
month
,
the
imprison
family
look
forth
on
the
external
world
,
and
be
dazzle
and
bewilder
by
the
sight
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
himself
,
despite
his
sober
judgment
,
could
scarcely
believe
he
have
not
be
in
a
trance
during
the
whole
period
.
<EOS>
the
shop
be
scarcely
open
before
it
be
fill
with
customer
,
and
Leonard
and
Stephen
be
instantly
employ
.
<EOS>
but
the
grocer
would
sell
nothing
.
<EOS>
to
those
who
ask
for
any
article
he
possess
,
he
present
them
with
it
,
but
would
receive
no
payment
.
 
<EOS>
He
next
dispatch
Blaize
to
bring
together
all
the
poor
he
could
find
,
and
distribute
among
them
the
remainder
of
his
store
--
his
cask
of

,
his
salt
meat
,
his

,
his
biscuit
,
his
wine
--
in
short
,
