that
be
leave
.
 
<EOS>
"
this
I
give
,
"
he
say
,
"
as
a
thanksgiving
to
the
Lord
,
and
as
a
humble
testimony
of
gratitude
for
my
signal
deliverance
.
"
  
<EOS>
II
.
 
<EOS>
the
MIDNIGHT
MEETING
.
 
<EOS>
the
first
day
of
his
deliverance
be
spend
by
the
grocer
in
the
praiseworthy
manner
before
relate
,
he
lay
his
head
upon
his
pillow
with
a
feeling
of
satisfaction
such
as
he
have
not
for
month
experience
.
<EOS>
a
very
remarkable
dream
occur
to
him
that
night
,
and
its
recollection
afterwards
afford
him
the
great
consolation
.
<EOS>
while
think
of
Amabel
,
and
of
the
delight
her
presence
would
have
afford
him
,
slumber
stole
upon
him
,
and
his
dream
be
naturally
influence
by
his
previous
meditation
.
<EOS>
It
appear
to
him
that
he
be
alone
within
his
house
,
and
while
visit
one
of
the
upper
room
,
which
have
formerly
be
appropriate
to
his
lose
daughter
,
he
notice
a
small
door
in
the
wall
that
have
never
before
attract
his
attention
.
<EOS>
He
immediately
push
against
it
,
and
yield
to
the
touch
,
it
admit
him
to
an
apartment
with
which
he
seem
acquaint
,
though
he
could
not
recall
the
time
when
he
have
see
it
.
<EOS>
It
be
large
and
gloomy
,
panel
with
dark
and
lustrous
oak
,
and
fill
with
rich
but
decay
furniture
.
<EOS>
at
the
further
end
stand
a
large
antique
bed
,
hang
round
with
tarnished
brocade
curtain
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
shudder
at
the
sight
,
for
he
remember
to
have
hear
Doctor
Hodges
assert
,
that
in
such
a
bed
,
and
in
such
a
room
as
this
,
his
daughter
have
breathe
her
last
.
<EOS>
some
one
appear
to
be
within
the
bed
,
and
rush
forward
with
a
throb
heart
,
and
a
foreboding
of
what
be
to
follow
,
he
behold
the
form
of
Amabel
.
<EOS>
yes
,
there
she
be
,
with
feature
like
those
she
wear
on
earth
,
but
clothe
with
such
celestial
beauty
,
and
bear
the
impress
of
such
serene
happiness
,
that
the
grocer
feel
awe
-
strike
as
he
gaze
at
her
!
 
<EOS>
"
Approach
,
my
father
,
"
say
the
visionary
form
,
in
a
voice
so
musical
that
it
thrill
through
his
frame--"approach
,
and
let
what
you
now
hear
be
for
ever
grave
upon
your
heart
.
<EOS>
do
not
lament
me
more
,
but
rather
rejoice
that
I
be
remove
from
trouble
,
and
in
the
enjoyment
of
supreme
felicity
.
<EOS>
such
a
state
you
will
yourself
attain
.
<EOS>
You
have
run
the
good
race
,
and
will
assuredly
reap
your
reward
.
<EOS>
comfort
<EOS>
my
dear
mother
,
my
brother
,
my
little
sister
,
with
the
assurance
of
what
I
tell
you
,
and
bid
them
dry
their
tear
.
<EOS>
I
can
now
read
the
secret
of
all
heart
,
and
know
how
true
be
Leonard
Holt
's
love
for
me
,
and
how
deep
and
sincere
be
his
present
sorrow
.
<EOS>
but
I
be
not
permit
to
appear
to
him
as
I
now
appear
to
you
.
<EOS>
often
have
I
hear
him
invoke
me
in
accent
of
the
wildest
despair
,
and
have
float
past
him
on
the
midnight
breeze
,
but
could
neither
impart
consolation
to
him
nor
make
him
sensible
of
my
presence
,
because
his
grief
be
sinful
.
<EOS>
bid
him
be
comfort
.
<EOS>
bid
him
put
a
due
control
upon
his
feeling
.
<EOS>
bid
him
open
his
heart
anew
,
and
he
shall
yet
be
happy
,
yet
love
again
,
and
have
his
love
requite
.
<EOS>
farewell
,
dear
father
!
"
 
<EOS>
and
with
these
word
the
curtain
of
the
bed
close
.
<EOS>
the
grocer
stretch
out
his
arm
to
draw
them
aside
,
and
in
the
effort
awake
.
<EOS>
He
sleep
no
more
that
night
,
but
dwelt
with
unutterable
delight
on
the
word
he
have
hear
.
<EOS>
on
rise
,
his
first
object
be
to
seek
out
Leonard
,
and
to
relate
his
vision
to
him
.
<EOS>
the
apprentice
listen
in
speechless
wonder
,
and
remain
for
some
time
lose
in

.
 
<EOS>
"
from
any
other

than
yourself
,
sir
,
"
he

,
at

,
"
I
may
have
doubt
this
singular
story
,
but
come
from
you
,
I
attach
implicit

to

.
<EOS>
I
_
<EOS>
will
_
obey
your
saint
daughter
's
injunction
;
<EOS>
I
_
will
<EOS>
_
struggle
against
the
grief
that
overwhelm
me
,
and
will
try
to
hope
that
her
word
may
be
fulfil
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
will
do
wisely
,
"
rejoin

Bloundel
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
after
breakfast
we
will
walk
together
to
the
farmhouse
you
speak
of
at
Kensal
Green
,
and
if
its

should
prove
willing
to
receive
my
family
for
a
few
week
,
I
will
remove
them
thither
at
once
.
"
 
<EOS>
Leonard
applaud
his
master
's
resolution
,
express
his
firm
conviction
that
Farmer
Wingfield
would
readily
accede
to
the
proposal
,
and
the
rest

the
family
have
by
this

assemble
,

.
<EOS>
as
soon
as

be
over
,
Mr.
Bloundel
intrust
the
care
of
the
shop
to
Stephen
and
Blaize
,
and
accompany
by
Leonard
,
set
forth
.
<EOS>
on
the
way
to
the
west
end
of
the
town
,
the
grocer
meet
one
or
two
of
his
old
friend
,
and
they
welcome
each
other
like
man
rise

.
<EOS>
Their
course
take
them
through
Saint
Giles
's
,
where
the
plague
have
rage
with
the
great
severity
,
and
where
many
house
be
still
without

.
 
<EOS>
"
if
all
have
act
as
I
have
do
,
"
sigh

,
as

at
these
desolate
habitation
,
"
<EOS>
how
many
life
,
under
God
's

,
would
have
be
save
!
"
 
<EOS>
"
in
my
opinion
,
sir
,
"
reply

,
"
you
owe
your

as
much
to
your
piety
as

your

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
have
place
my
trust
on
high
,
"
rejoin
the
grocer
,
"
and
have
not
be
forsake
.
<EOS>
and
yet
many
evil
doer
have
escape
;
amongst
others--
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
know
whom
you
mean
,

,
"
interrupt

,
with

,
"
but
a
day
of
retribution
will
arrive
for

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
more
of
this
,
"
rejoin
the
grocer
,
severely
.
"
<EOS>
remember
the
solemn
injunction
you
have
receive
.
"
 
<EOS>
at
this
moment
they
observe
a
horseman
,
richly
attire
,
and
follow
by
a

of
attendant
,
ride

towards
them
.
<EOS>
both
instantly
recognise
him
.
<EOS>
the
apprentice
's
cheek
and
brow
flush
with
anger
,
and
Mr.
Bloundel
have
much
ado
to
control
his

.
<EOS>
It
be
the
Earl
of
Rochester
,
and
on
see
them
he
instantly
dismount
,
and
fling
his
bridle
to
one

attendant
,
advanced
towards
them
.
<EOS>
notice
the
fury
that
gleam
in
Leonard
's
eye
,
and

some

on
his
part
,
the
grocer
lay
his
hand
,
upon
his
arm
,
and
sternly
enjoin
him
to
calm

.
 
<EOS>
by
this
time
,
the
earl
have
reach
them
.
"
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
,
"
he
say
,
in
a
tone
of
much
emotion
,
and
with
a
look
that
seem
to
bespeak
contrition
.
<EOS>
"
I
hear
that
you
have
open
your
house
yesterday
,
and
be
about
to
call
upon
you
.
<EOS>
I
have
a
few
word
to
say
to
you
on
a
subject
painful
to
both
of
us
,
but
doubly
painful
to
me
--
your
daughter
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
must
decline
to
hear
them
,
my
lord
,
"
reply
the
grocer
,
coldly
;
"
nor
shall
you
ever
cross
my
threshold
again
with
my
consent
.
<EOS>
My
poor
child
be
now
at
peace
.
<EOS>
You
can
do
her
no
further
injury
,
and
must
settle
your
own
account
with
your
maker
.
<EOS>
"
 
"
do
not
refuse
me
your
forgiveness
,
"
implore
the
earl
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
make
every
reparation
in
my
power
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
You
_
can
_
make
none
,
"
reply
the
grocer
,
repel
him
;
"
and
as
to
my
forgiveness
,
I
neither
refuse
it
nor
accord

.
<EOS>
I
pray
your
lordship
to
let
me
pass
.
<EOS>
the
sole
favour
I
ask
of
you
be
to
come
near
me
no
more
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
obey
you
,
"
reply

earl
.
<EOS>
"
stay
,
"
he
add
to
Leonard
,
who
stand

,
regard

.
<EOS>
"
I
would
give
you
a
piece

.
<EOS>
Your
life
be
in
danger
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I
can
easily
guess
from
whom
,
"
reply
the
apprentice
,
scornfully
.
 
<EOS>
"
You
mistake
,
"
rejoin
Rochester
;
"
you
have
nothing
to
apprehend

.
<EOS>
You
have
promise
to
meet
some
one
to
-
night
,
"
he

,
in

low

as
to

.
"
<EOS>
do
not
go
.
"
 
<EOS>
"
Your
lordship
's
warning
will
not
deter
me
,
"
rejoin

.
 
<EOS>
"
as
you
will
,
"
rejoin
Rochester
,
turn
away
.
<EOS>
and
spring
upon
his
horse
,
and
strike
his

into
his
side
,
he
dash

,
while

and

.
<EOS>
in
less
than
half
an
hour
they
reach
the
little
village
of
Paddington
,
then
consist
of
a
few
house
,
but
now
one
of
the
most
populous
and
important
parish
of
the
metropolis
,
and
speedily
gain
the
open
country
.
<EOS>
even
at
this
dreary
season
the
country
have
charm
,
which
Mr.
Bloundel
,
after
his
long
confinement
,
could
fully
appreciate
.
<EOS>
His
eye
roam
over
the
wide
prospect
;
and
the
leafless
tree
,
the
bare
hedge
,
and
the
frost
-
bind
field
seem
pleasant
in
his
sight
.
 
<EOS>
He
quicken
his
pace
,
and
be
wholly
indifferent
to
the
cold
,
greatly
enjoy
the
exercise
.
<EOS>
Leonard
point
out
to
him
the
spot
where
the
fugitive
from
the
plague
have
pitch
their
tent
,
and
also
the
pest
-
house
near
Westbourne
Green
,
where
he
himself
have
be
receive
during
his
second
attack
of
the
distemper
,
and
which
be
now
altogether
abandon
.
 
<EOS>
soon
after
this
,
they
mount
the
hill
beyond
Kensal
Green
,
and
approach
the
farmhouse
.
<EOS>
Leonard
descry
Wingfield
near
one
of
the
barn
,
and
hail
him
,
he
immediately
come
forward
.
<EOS>
on
be
inform
of
Mr.
Bloundel
's
desire
,
he
at
once
assent
,
and
take
them
into
the
house
,
mention
the
matter
to
his
dame
,
who
be
quite
of
the
same
opinion
as
himself
.
 
<EOS>
"
the
only
difference
between
us
<EOS>
,
"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
recollect

"

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

surprise

,
offer

.

.
    
<EOS>
BOOK
the

.
 
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
I.
 
<EOS>
the

.
 
<EOS>

smoke
.
<EOS>
God
help
us
!
"
<EOS>
and
the
exclamation
be
follow
by
fearful

from
within
,
follow
by
the
appearance
of
a
woman
,
hold
two
little
child
in
her

,
at

window
.
 
<EOS>
"
this
must
be
money
,
"
say

,
utterly
heedless
of
the
fearful
scene
occur
above
,
and
take

bag
and
chink

;
"
silver
,
by
the
sound
.
<EOS>
Shall
we
make

?
"
 
<EOS>
"
no
,
no
,
"
reply

,
"
we
must
not
run
any
risk
for
such

.
<EOS>
let

.
"
 
<EOS>
at

,

,
who
have

,
again

,

,

,

,

place

,
as
to

.
<EOS>
tie

,

's

,

.
<EOS>
They

;

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

have

of

's

,

be

of

,

be

.
<EOS>
the

too
have

;

of

be

,

be

with
person

,

have

bed
to

.
<EOS>
all
be

and

.
<EOS>
the

's
,

's
,

,

,

,

on

,
prove

be

.
 
<EOS>
to

,

in

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

"

's

.
"
 
<EOS>

now

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>
no

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
another

,

,
in

-

,

,

,

,

be

,

that

be

,

.
 
<EOS>
meantime

in

-

,

continue

,

.
<EOS>
all

be

,
and
of

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
hundred

.
<EOS>
the

be

.
<EOS>
many

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

present

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
night

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

have

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
"
 
<EOS>
"
away
,

!
"
<EOS>

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
the

,
"

,

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

!

.
<EOS>

,
Hubert

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
this

not

.
<EOS>

;

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

's

they

,

's

!
"
 
<EOS>

listen

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

have

.
<EOS>
down

!
<EOS>
down

!
"
 
<EOS>

,

;

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

on

.
<EOS>
Solomon
Eagle
be

,

.
<EOS>
another

of

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
the

within

be

;

;
and
the

and
other

withinside
catching
fire
,
the

ascend
to
the
roof
,
and
kindle

rafter
.
 
<EOS>
great

be
now

.
<EOS>
a
few
of
the
cumbrous
and

of

be
bring
to

,
but
no

.
<EOS>
all
the

,
pipe
,

be

,

-

be

be

,

connect

empty
.
<EOS>
to

,
the

be
out
,
and
it
be
not
only
difficult
,
but

,
to

water
from

.
<EOS>
the

supply
serve
rather
to

flame
.
<EOS>
all
sort
of
rumour
prevail
among

.
<EOS>
It
could
no

be
doubt
that
the
fire
,
which
keep

in

,
be

,

,

both
of
which
nation
the
country
be
then
at
war
,
and
the
most
fearful
anticipation
that
it
be
only
the
prelude
of
a
sudden
invasion
be
entertain
.
<EOS>
some
conjecture
it
may
be
the
work
of
the
Papists
;
and
it
chance
that
a
professor
of
that
religion
be
discover
among

mob
,
he
be
with

rescue
from

,
and

to
Newgate
.
<EOS>
other

,

be

suspect
of
be

,

.
 
<EOS>
this
,

satisfy

,
do

,

.
<EOS>
every

a

be
turn

,
and
by

.
<EOS>
the
plunderer
have
form

into
band
,

--
carry

,

,
and

,

into
cellar
,
broach

of

and

,
and

.
<EOS>
hundred
of
person
who
do
not
join
in

make
free
with
the
content
of
the
cellar
,
and
a
large

of
the
concourse
be
soon
in
a

of

.
 
<EOS>
thus
,
wild

and

of

be

of

and

child
.
<EOS>
It
be
indeed

to

and
bed

ride

into

;
nor

to
behold
other
rouse
from

at

,
and
by

.
<EOS>
still
,
fan
by

,

,

press

,

,

;

,

.
 
<EOS>
to

.
<EOS>

PROGRESS

.

,
and
produce
a

,
threaten
to
fire

.
<EOS>
the

,

,
have
receive

,
be

,

.
<EOS>
the

-

then
fire
,

;
and

,

door
have

,

.
<EOS>
They

,
but
find
he
have

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
the

have

,

<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

"

;
"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

Gunpowder
!
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

?
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Lord
,

!
<EOS>

?
"
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

I

,

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
a

,

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
It
chance

,

,
have

that

,

.
<EOS>
the

,

be

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>
the

have

.
<EOS>
It

mention
,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>
light

,

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
one

,
note

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
 
<EOS>
Leonard
remain

.
<EOS>
He

,
in

,

,

possess

.
<EOS>
He

that

of

be

to

of

,

.
<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
there
lie

,
which

,
now

far
-
see

.
<EOS>
the

seem

form

--
many
-

in

,
and
re
-

in

.
 
<EOS>
nor
be

aspect
of
the
city
less

.
<EOS>
the
innumerable

and
spire
of
the

rise

and

through
the
wavering

of
flame
,
and
every
now
<EOS>
and
then

of
them
would

or

,
as
if

up
by

.
<EOS>
for

,

seem

regular

,
but
when

fall
upon
well
material
,
it
rear
its

crest

,
change

,
and
burn
with

.
<EOS>
Leonard
watch
it
thread
narrow
alley
,
and
fire
every
less
habitation
in
its
course
,
kindle
some
great
hall
or
other
structure
,
whose
remoteness
seem
to
secure

from

.
<EOS>
at
this

,
the

of
the

resemble
that
of
a
thousand
furnace
.
<EOS>
ever
and
anon
,
it
be
break
by
a

like

,
occasion
by

of
some

.
<EOS>
then

come
a

of

like

,
follow
by
a
shower
of
fiery
flake
and
spark
blow
aloft
,
like
the

of
some

.
<EOS>
mix
with
the
roaring
of
the
flame
,
the

of
fall
roof
,
the
cracking
of
timber
,
be
a

,

.

a
box
to
carry
off
at

's

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
do

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
wond

i
would
.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

I

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

no
do

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>

take

,

,
"
I

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

--

.
"
 
<EOS>

then

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
drum

.
<EOS>

be

;

on

.

.
"

?

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
Lord

.
 
<EOS>

,

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

,
glance

.

.

_

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
ah
!

;

"
 
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

;
"

,

.

?

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
"

?

.

,

.

,

.
 
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

.

"

.

<EOS>

,

,

?
"

.
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
 
<EOS>

,

that

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"
rejoin

,

.

,
"
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
wear

,

<EOS>
to

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

,

:
_

_
.
"
<EOS>

also
liken

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
a
dreadful
bow
<EOS>
it

,
"

,
"

's

;

,

,

<EOS>
God
's

not

any

,
but

bow
have
fire
in

,
and

's

,
and
his

to
destroy

with

.
"
 
<EOS>
as

draw

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
never

.
<EOS>
none

,

to

,

be

,

.
<EOS>

appear

.
<EOS>
hall
,

,

,

,

,

more

.
<EOS>
traveller

.
<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
VI
.
 
<EOS>
how
the

.
 
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

--

Guildhall

.
<EOS>

my

,
and

be

.
"
 
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

the

.

CONCLUSION
.
 
<EOS>
Lord
Argentine
proceed
,
as
direct
by
the
king
,
to
the
eastern
end
of
Tower
-
street
,
where
he
find
Lord
Craven
,
and
have
deliver
him
the
king
's
missive
,
and
show
him
the
signet
,
they
proceed
to
the
western
side
of
the
Tower
Dock
,
and
have
procure
a
sufficient
number
of
miner
and
engineer
,
together
with
a
supply
of
powder
from
the
fortress
,
commence
undermine
the
whole
of
the
row
of
habitation
call
Tower
-
bank
,
on
the

of
the
dock
,
have
first
,
it
be
scarcely
necessary
to
state
,
take
care
to
clear

of
their

.
<EOS>
the
powder
deposit
,
the
train
be
fire
,
and
the

blow
into

air
.
<EOS>
at
this
time
the
whole
of
the
western
side
of
the
Tower
Moat
be
cover
with

house
and

,
and
,

's

,
Lord

suggest

that
they
should
be
destroy
.
<EOS>
the
latter
acquiescing
,
they
proceed
to
their
task
,
and
in
a
short
time
the
whole
of
the
building
of
whatever
description
,
from
the
bulwark
-
gate
to
the
city
postern
,
at
the
north
of
the
Tower
,
and
nearly
opposite
the
Bowyer
Tower
,
be
destroy
.
<EOS>
long
before
this
be

they
be
join
by
the
Duke
of
York
,
who
lend
his

to
the
task
,
and
when
night
come

,
a

of

yard
in

,
have
be
form
between
the
ancient

and
the
danger
with
which

be
threaten
.
 
<EOS>
meantime
the
conflagration
continue
to
rage
with
unabated
fury
.
<EOS>
It
burn
throughout
the
whole
of
Monday
night
,
and
have
destroy
Saint
Paul
's
,
as
before
relate
,
pour
down
Ludgate
-
hill
,
consume
all
in
its
way
,
and
,
cross
Fleet
Bridge
,
commence
its
ravage
upon
the
great
thoroughfare
adjoin
it
.
<EOS>
on
Tuesday
an
immense
tract
be
on
fire
.
<EOS>
all
Fleet
-
street
,
as
far
as
the
Inner
Temple
,
Ludgate
-
hill
,
and
the
whole
of
the
city
eastward
,
along
the
bank
of
the
Thames
,
up
to
the
Tower
Dock
,
where
the
devastation
be
check
by
the
vast
gap
of
house
demolish
,
be
in

.
<EOS>
from
thence
the
boundary
of
the
fire
extend
to
the
end
of
Mark
-
lane
,
Lime
-
street
,
and
Leadenhall
,
the
strong
wall
of
which
resist
its
fury
.
<EOS>
ascend
again
by
the
Standard
on
Cornhill
,
Threadneedle
-
street
,
and
Austin
Friars
,
it
embrace
Drapers
'

,
and
the
whole
mass
of
building
to
the
west

Throgmorton
-

.
<EOS>

next
proceed
to
the
then
new
building
behind
Saint
Margaret
's
,
Lothbury
,
and
so
on
westward
to
the
upper

-

,
whence
it
spread
to
the
second

in
London
Wall
,
and
destroy
the
rampart
and
suburb
as
far
as
Cripplegate
,
consume
little
wood
-
street
,
Mungwell
-
street
,
and
the
whole
of
the
city
wall
on
the
west
as
far
as
Aldersgate
.
<EOS>
pass
a
little
to
the
north
of
Saint
Sepulchre
's
,
which
it
destroy
,
it
cross
Holborn
Bridge
,
and
ascend
Saint
Andrew's
-
hill
,
pass
the
end
of
Shoe
-
lane
,
and
so

the
end

Fetter
-

.
<EOS>
the
whole
of
the
building
contain
within
this
boundary
be
now
on
fire
,
and
burn
with
terrific
fury
.
<EOS>
and
so
they
continue
till
the
middle
of
Wednesday
,
when
the
wind
abate
,
and
an
immense
quantity
of
house
be
demolish
accord
to
Lord
Argentine
's
plan
,
the
conflagration
be
get
under
;
and
though
it
break
out
in
several
place
after
that
time
,
little
mischief
be
do
,
and
it
may
be
say
to
have
cease
on
the
middle
of

.
 
<EOS>
on
Saturday
morning
in
that
week
,
soon
after

,
a
young
man
,
plainly
yet
richly

in
the
habiliment
then

by
person
of

rank
,
take

the
smoulder

of

,
and
along
the
rank
of
ruin
and

wall
denote
the
habitation
that
have
once
constitute
fleet
-

.
<EOS>
It
be
with
no
little
risk
,
and
some

,
that
he
could
force
his
way
,
now
clamber
over
heap
of

ashe
,
now
pass

wall
,
which

after

have

pass

--
now
creep
under
an
immense
pile
of
blacken
rafter
;
but
he
at
length
reach
Fleet
Bridge
,
where
he
pause
to
gaze
at
the
scene
of

around

.
 
<EOS>
It
be
indeed
a
melancholy
sight
,
and
draw
tear
to
his
eye
.
<EOS>
the
ravage
of
the
fire
be
almost
inconceivable
.
<EOS>
great
beam
be
burn
to
charcoal
--
stone
calcine
,
and
as
white
as
snow
,
and
such
wall
and
tower
as
be
leave
stand
be
so
damaged
that
their
instant
fall
be
to
be
expect
.
<EOS>
the
very
water
in
the
well
and
fountain
be
boil
,
and
even
the
muddy
Fleet
send
forth
a
hot
steam
.
<EOS>
the
fire
still
linger
in
the
low
part
of
many
habitation
,
especially
where
wine
,
spirit
,
or
inflammable
good
have
be
keep
;
and
these
"
vorago
of
subterranean

,
"
<EOS>
as
Evelyn
term
them
,
still
emit
flame
,
together
with
a

and

.
<EOS>
undismaye
by
the
danger
of
the
path
he
have
to
traverse
,
the
young
man
ascend
Ludgate
-
hill
,
still
encounter
the
same
devastation
,
and
pass
through
the
ruin
gateway
,
the
end
of
which
remain
perfect
,
approach
what
have
once
be
Saint
Paul
's
Cathedral
.
<EOS>
mount
a
heap
of
rubbish
at
the
end
of
Ludgate
street
,
he
gaze
at
the
mighty
ruin
,
which
look
more
like
the
remain
of
a
city
than
those
of

single

.
 
<EOS>
the
solid
wall
and
buttress
be
split
and
rent
asunder
;
enormous
stone
be
splinter
and
calcine
by
the
heat
;
and
vast
flake
have
scale
from
off
the
pillar
,
give
them
a
hoary
and
almost

.
<EOS>
Its
enormous
extent
be
now
for
the
first
time
clearly
see
,
and
,
strange
to
say
it
look
twice
as
large
in
ruin
as
when
entire
.
<EOS>
the
central
tower
be
still
stand
,
but
chip
,
break
,
and
calcine
,
like
the
rest
of
the
structure
,
by

heat
of

.
<EOS>
part
of
the
roof
,
in
its
fall
,
break
through
the
solid
floor
of
the
choir
,
which
be
of
immense
thickness
,
into
Saint
Faith
's
,
and
destroy
the
magazine
of
book
and
paper
deposit
there
by

.
<EOS>
the
portico
,
erect
by
Inigo
Jones
,
and
which
find
so
much
favour
in
Evelyn
's
eye
,
that

describe

as
"
comparable
to
any
in
Europe
,
"
and
particularly
deplore

,
share

of

--
<EOS>
the
only
part
leave
uninjured
be
the

,
the

on

.
 
<EOS>
have
satiate
himself
with
this
sad
but

,
the

,
with

,

,

,

a

.
<EOS>
on

,

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
such

that
have

,
that

have

.
<EOS>
the

and

's

point

,

,

,

--

be

,

,

wide
--

.
<EOS>
but
,
alas
!
<EOS>
how
change
be
that

spot
.
<EOS>

he
seek
be
a
mere

.
<EOS>
while
gaze

,

hear

,

,
behold

Bloundel
and

,
force

what
have

be

.
<EOS>
a

pass
between

,
and

gaze

.
<EOS>
tear
force
themselves
into
his
eye
,
and
his

be
no
less

.
<EOS>
as

turn
to

,

to

:
 
<EOS>
"
how
be

,
Leonard
,
that
I
see

in
this
gay

?
<EOS>
surely
,
the
present
be
not
a
fitting
season
for
such
idle
display
.
"
 
<EOS>
Lord
Argentine
,
for
such
it
be
,
now
explain
to
the
wonder
-

grocer
all
that
have
occur

,

have
intend
come

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

Farmer
Wingfield
and

?
"

.
<EOS>
"

have
be

.
"
 
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

injury
receive

;
but

--
nay
,

--

will

-

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"
that
be
well
,
"

;
"

,

--

,

--

.
 
<EOS>

"

.
 
<EOS>
"
oh
!

"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
 
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
,

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
"

such

,
"

,

.
 
<EOS>
three
day
after
this
,
Lord
Argentine
be
unite
to
the
Lady
<EOS>
Isabella.--the
king
,
as

have

,

.
<EOS>
the
Earl
of
Rochester
be
present
,
together

and

wife
,

.
<EOS>
another
marriage
also
take

on

between

and
Patience
.
<EOS>
both
union
,
it
be
satisfactory
to
be
able
to
state
,

,

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

,
be

under

.
<EOS>

settle

,
where

live
to

,

.
 
<EOS>
Mr.
Bloundel
sustain
only
a

loss
by

fire
.
<EOS>
another

be
erect
on
the

,
where
he
carry

as

and

before
,
until
,

nature
,
he
be

,
and

by

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

his

.
<EOS>
all

turn

,

in

.
<EOS>
Stephen
rise

high
civic

,
and

younger
obtain

.
<EOS>

Christiana
become
Lady
Argentine
,
be
wed
to
the
eld
son
of
the

and

.
 
<EOS>
Mike
Macascree
,
the
piper
,
and
Bell
,
find

with

.
 
<EOS>
as
to
Lord
and

,
theirs
be
a

.
<EOS>
devotedly
attach
to

,
the

seem
only
to

,
and
he
well
repay

.
<EOS>
by
sedulously

his
talent
and

,
which
be
considerable
,
he
be
enable
to
reflect
credit
upon

high
rank
to

have

.
<EOS>

live
to

new

complete
by
Sir

,
and
often

,
but

have

when
,

,

have

OLD
SAINT
paul's.
